definitions as used in this section bike path is a designated public way intended for bicyclists park or other park property park property means all real and personal property including but not limited to land buildings facilities equipment and amenities as described in the parks definition parks and other areas operated and maintained by the city of maitland parks and recreation department include but are not limited to parks playgrounds recreation fields museums buildings boat ramps lakes streams canals channels lagoons therein and all public service facilities located on or in grounds waters building and structures in the city of maitland which are under the control of or assigned for upkeep maintenance or operation by the parks and recreation department parks and recreation director is the parks and recreation director of the city of maitland florida or his designee special events are public or private assemblies or events that could conflict with the normal use and operation of the park special written permit is for exceptions to established park rules and regulations and is issued by the parks and recreation department  enforcement of park rules a the rules regulations and permits contained in this document are enforceable by all law enforcement officers and parks and recreation department personnel b parents or guardians will be held strictly responsible for the actions of minors c any violation of any of the provisions of this section may result in loss of park privileges and may be punished as provided in section 18  lost and found any lost articles shall be immediately turned over to parks and recreation personnel on site otherwise lost articles shall be turned into the parks and recreation department articles of value ie cash jewelry weapons etc will be turned over to the maitland police department for safe keeping the police department will make a good faith effort to contact the owners title to the lost article will remain with the owner for six 6 months after six 6 months the unclaimed article will be placed in the city auction for sale or converted to use by the city when appropriate  park hours a parks are to be opened to the public every day of the year except for emergencies park hours for each park shall be posted b any park or park area may be closed in the interest of public welfare at the discretion of the parks and recreation director c reservation of specific park facilities during normal park hours by private groups may be granted by special written permit  special events special events shall require a special events permit to be issued by the police department in accordance with of the city 6 prohibited activities in parks a it shall be unlawful for any person to do any one or more of the following in any park unless specifically permitted to do so by a special written permit issued by the city manager or his designee pursuant to this chapter except for activities of a governmental agency within the scope of its governmental authority 1 possess sell give or serve any alcoholic beverage as defined by fs  561014 2 carry fire or discharge any rocket or other fireworks of any description 3 interfere with hinder or oppose any park and recreation personnel in the discharge of their duties or in the enforcement of the park rules and regulations 4 operate audio equipment at a sound level that disturbs other park patrons 5 engage in noisy activities in violation of section 1010 of the city 6 conduct themselves in an improper manner so as to offend or disrupt park visitors 7 change clothes except in designated facilities 8 set a fire except in grills provided by the city no bonfires or open fires will be permitted on dog island 9 enter or remain on park property outside of posted hours 10 enter upon any part of any park property which is under construction or closed to the general public 11 mark deface tamper with damage displace or remove any park property 12 search or excavate or construct or erect any structure or run or string any public utility on park property 13 disturb andor interfere with wildlife except in the interest of public welfare 14 tamper with or remove any plant life or landscape element 15 sell anything tangible or intangible or solicit for any purpose 16 distribute or circulate any written or printed matter 17 engage in recreational activities such as football baseball softball horseshoes tennis volleyball badminton or any other activity involving propelled objects such as balls arrows shuttlecocks frisbees roller skates or skateboards except in areas not in conflict with other activities 18 swim or wade except in designated areas 19 swim or wade except during posted hours 20 wear a swimsuit resulting in indecent exposure of the person or merit criticism based on conformity of swimming suits with commonly accepted standards in compliance with existing florida state statutes 21 wash with or without soap or other cleaners in any swimming area 22 scuba dive in any park waters 23 use any device designed to artificially hold a person afloat unless supervised by a responsible party 24 allow children under the age of twelve 12 in designated swimming areas unaccompanied by a parent or a person designated by the parent 25 fishing where prohibited by signage 26 boating except in accordance with of the city 27 litter on any park property or waters all refuse must be deposited in receptacles provided for trash disposal 28 post or affix any signage on park property 29 drive or park any motor vehicle on any park property which has not been designated for such purpose 30 drive a motor vehicle at a rate of speed exceeding ten 10 miles per hour on any park property unless a greater speed limit is posted 31 enter or exit from any park property in any motor vehicle except on entrances and exits established for such purposes 32 load or unload except in areas designated for that purpose 33 use bicycles personalized motor vehicles roller skates or skateboards on vehicular roads and parking areas in excess of posted speed limits and on designated bike paths in excess of fifteen 15 miles per hour 34 park bicycles in such a way as to obstruct circulation of traffic paths or cause damage or harm to any park property or plant life where available bicycle racks must be used 35 use human powered vehicles in conflict with traffic circulation or other park activities b any aggrieved applicant shall have the right to appeal the denial of a permit under section 1146 to the city council the appeal shall be taken by the applicant within five 5 days after the receipt of the notice of denial by filing a written notice with the city manager or his designee the city manager or his designee shall place the appeal on the next available agenda for consideration by the city council  animals in city parks a animals are allowed in city parks under the following conditions 1 the animal must be under the control of a responsible owner  2 the animal must be on a leash at all times  3 the animal shall not be tethered to any object at any time  4 the responsible person in control of the animal shall not permit the animal to approach within 10 feet of facilities ie picnic tables active recreation facilities buildings etc meant for human utilization  and 5 the responsible person in control of the animal shall remove any feces deposited by the animal failure to do so immediately shall constitute an additional violation of this section b no animals shall be allowed in the lake destiny soccer field the maitland ballfield complex and the maitland cemetery c animals are allowed in the maitland community park in designated areas only d animals employed by any governmental agency and companions of the physically challenged are exempted from this section  61394   32700   71111   92611 secs 1151113  reserved article ii  boats boating and use of waterways division 1  generally secs 1114  reserved editors note of adopted mar 25 199 repealed former  1114 which pertained to definition and derived from  and  adopted dec 9 1985 adoption of state law and coast guard regulations the provisions of florida statutes united states coast guard inland navigation rules are hereby adopted the same as if set forth herein    32591 violations any person violating any provision of this article shall be punished as for a violation of this ordinances under the following provisions for a nonmoving violation the fine shall be eightynine dollars $8900 for a moving violation the fine shall be ninetynine dollars $9900 officers may elect to write violators a violation notice by means of a florida uniform boating citation which shall be processed clerks office or by means of a city form notice of in which case the fine shall be the same but the appeals andor hearing process shall be before the special magistrate of the city of maitland during a regularly scheduled monthly hearing date appearing before the magistrate and being found to have committed the violation may result in additional fines not to exceed two hundred fifty $25000 and an administrative cost to be determined by the magistrate any judgments rendered may be enforceable as a lien against property and listed as debt owed to the city of maitland on credit reports failure to arrange for a hearing or pay the fine within thirty 30 days will result in the persons privilege to operate a boat being suspended and if the person is an owner or coowner of a vessel the chain of lakes pass may be suspended until such time as payment is made no day pass shall be issued to any such vessel if the yearly permit has been suspended    32591   72709 landing seaplanes prohibited  exception it shall be unlawful to land a float or seaplane on any lake or waterway of the city except in an emergency    32591 molesting tampering with boats  setting hazardous objects adrift it shall be unlawful for any person to a molest tamper with damage destroy trespass upon or cast loose or set adrift any boat or boats belonging to another or to disturb destroy steal take or carry away any of the contents fixtures or appurtenances of any boat belonging to another b set adrift any object which may constitute a hazard to the safe operation of any boat or person skiing  reserved editors note of adopted mar 25 199 repealed former  1119 which pertained to boats or hazardous objects adrift to be secured and derived from  temporary obstructions extending from shoreline to be lighted it shall be unlawful for any person to leave or permit any temporary obstruction barge dredge temporary pier dock or vessel to extend further than forty 40 feet from the shoreline or to anchor any float vessel buoy or other hazard to navigation more than forty 40 feet from the shoreline unless lighted between the hours of sunset and sunrise to show the overall length of any such temporary barge dredge vessel or other obstruction    32591 regattas and other organized aquatic activitiesregulations generally persons or organizations sponsoring rowing or sailing regattas swimming meets or other similar organized aquatic activities on the waterways of the city shall apply to the city manager for a permit and shall furnish proof of insurance satisfactory to the city attorney to protect the interest of the city the participants spectators and the public at least fifteen 15 days prior to such event    32591 samesponsors to provide for traffic control persons or organizations sponsoring rowing or sailing regattas swimming meets or other similar organized aquatic activities on the waterways of the city shall notify the maitland police department in writing at least fifteen 15 days prior to such event in order that appropriate arrangements for safety and navigation may be assured and shall provide adequate traffic control at their own expense as may be required by the police department    32591 water sports a vessel operators shall immediately retrieve persons who have fallen from or voluntarily stopped waterskiing wakeboarding surfboarding kneeboarding aquaplaning watersleding tubing or riding other similar devices behind their vessels equipment used in such sports shall be retrieved only after such people are safely in their vessel b vessel operators shall not tow anyone on waterskis wakeboards surfboards kneeboards aquaplanes watersleds tubes or other similar devices within one hundred 100 feet of the shoreline nor in canals or under bridges c waterskiers wakeboarders surfboarders kneeboarders aquaplaners watersledders tubers or persons using similar devices being pulled by vessels shall stay clear of the shoreline a minimum distance of one hundred 100 feet they shall not use such devices in canals or under bridges operators shall not permit persons engaged in above listed activities to use safety buoys as slalom markers d all persons riding personal watercraft jet skis waveriders motorized surfboards and other similar vessels windsurfers wakeboards waterskis surfboards being towed or free floating on boat wakes kneeboards aquaplanes watersleds tubes or other similar devices shall wear a properly sized us coast guard approved personal flotation device pfd type i ii or iii e all boats and personal watercraft towing water skiers wakeboarders surfboarders aquaplaners sledders or tubers shall have two persons in the boat or on the personal watercraft one facing aft and the other facing forward f operators of vessels towing skiers wakeboarders surfboarders aquaplaners sledders or tubers where practicable shall take turns in a counterclockwise direction    12985   32591   72709 boat to accompany swimmer more than 100 feet from shore it shall be unlawful for any person to swim further from the shore than one hundred 100 feet unless accompanied by a boat  skin divers to be accompanied by boat and flag  diving in canals prohibited no person shall scuba or skin dive unless accompanied by a boat and identified by a scuba or skin diving flag no person shall scuba or skin dive in any of the canals  regulation of slalom courses a permit for a skislalom course may be obtained from the city manager provided 1 an application including a set of plans showing the location of the course and the depth of the water is filed with the city manager 2 it does not create a navigational hazard or otherwise interfere with the public use of the waterways of the city 3 the structure is placed in a location with a minimum water depth of six 6 feet and shall be placed a minimum of three hundred 300 feet from any shoreline that is not under the ownership or control of the permittee 4 the buoys shall be of soft rubber or vinyl styrofoam or plastic bottles not to exceed one gallon in capacity  32591 secs 11271134  reserved hang gliding parachuting parasailing hot air ballooning and airboating prohibited hang gliding 12985   32591 division 2  waterways user fees required every owner or operator of an inboard or outboard motor vessel operating upon any waterway either partially or wholly within the corporate limits of the city shall be required to pay the city a user fee to offset the cost of patrolling and maintaining such waterways and shall at all times display an appropriate valid user fee receipt on said boat or the operator shall have in his possession a valid daily user fee receipt    32381   62989   72489   32591 prerequisites a in order to use a vessel on the citys waterways the owners shall give the make model horsepower length of vessel the state of florida registration number and certify that such vessel has all equipment required by the state of florida and the city of maitland owners of vessels carrying passengers for hire shall also present satisfactory evidence that said vessel has been safety inspected and found to be safe by the us coast guard auxiliary b no vessel equipped with an engine that exceeds the maximum horsepower recommended by the manufacturer of the vessel shall be issued a user fee receipt    32381   32591 collection agents the city manager or his designated agent is hereby authorized to collect such user fees and dispense such receipts    32381   62989   72489 issuance display of receipts  shape upon payment of the user fee required by this article two 2 receipts shall be issued to the payer of the user fee those receipts shall be affixed one on each side of the bow fore and aft of the state registration numbers user fee decals issued the year beginning  shall be triangular shape with a square used for the year beginning  and a circle for the year beginning  thereafter these shapes shall be repeated in the same sequence during each not invalidate the receipt provided the police department or finance department is notified within ten 10 days of such change in ownership the intention of the city council is that a user fee be paid and receipts issued for each motorboat utilizing such waterways regardless of ownership or transfer of ownership such receipts however are not transferable from one boat to another    32381   62989   72489 user fee schedule annual or daily user fees a daily user fee of six dollars $600 shall be paid prior to the operation of any motorboat in lieu of the daily user fee an annual use fee may be paid based upon the dollar amount and unit set forth in this subsection the unit shall be calculated by adding the length of the boat in feet rounded to the next higher whole foot together with the manufacturers advertised maximum horsepower of the engine or engines at maximum rpm rounded to the next higher whole horsepower the total of these two 2 numbers is the number of units assigned to each motorboat and will be the basis for calculating boat user fees length shall mean the measurement from end to end over the deck parallel to the center line excluding sheer the user fee shall be imposed by applying the unit for each boat times the users fee factor set forth below noncommercial annual commercial annual motorboat owned by city resident $050 $100 motorboat owned by nonresident of city $075 $150 annual user fees paid between january 1st and june 30th shall be onehalf 12 the aforementioned amount    32381   72682   62485   62989   72489   102708 special provision for dealers for individual vessels as required by section 1137 provided they comply with florida statute 32852    32381   62989   72489   32591 application of user fee revenues all revenues received by the city from payments of daily and annual user fees shall be expended for the patrol maintenance and improvement of lakes or waters including the navigability on the citys waterways as well as other boatingrelated activities in the city    32381   62989   72489 reciprocity with city of winter park at such time as the city of winter park shall adopt and have in effect an ordinance with sufficient similarity to of this to boats and containing a like reciprocity section all motorboats for which the user fee has been duly and properly paid to the city of winter park shall be permitted to be operated upon any waterway within the corporate limits of the city of maitland without the payment of any further user fee to the city of maitland or requirement for securing any user fee from the city of maitland    62989   72489 secs 11451158  reserved division 3  operation of boats operation of power boats by minors a no person under eighteen 18 years of age shall operate a powerdriven vessel on the waterways of the city without first obtaining a junior boating license or restricted junior boating license  from the maitland or winter park police departments such safety certificate may be obtained by 1 filing an application with the police department and upon presentation of evidence that they have satisfactorily completed the basic us coast guard auxiliary us power squadron or the florida boating safety course these courses approved by the lakes advisory board are proof completion of a boating safety course 2 passing a practical test administered by the police department in the operation of a power driven vessel similar in design and horsepower to the vessel such minor will regularly be operating and be issued a certificate of proficiency for the operation of that type vessel 3 a personal watercraft endorsement is required if the vessel to be operated is of the pwc design this is in addition to the junior boating license b such application shall be signed and verified before a person authorized to administer oaths by the father mother or guardian or in the event there is no parent or guardian by another responsible adult who is willing to assume the obligation imposed under this chapter upon a person signing the application of a minor the application shall contain a certification by the applicant that they can swim one hundred 100 feet c any negligence or willful misconduct of a minor under eighteen 18 years of age when operating a power driven vessel on the waterways of the city shall be imputed to the person who has signed the application of such minor which person shall be jointly and severally liable with such minor for any damage caused by such negligence or willful misconduct of such minor d if such person who signed an application of a minor shall file with the police department a verified written request that the safety certificate of such minor so granted be canceled or upon the death of the person who has signed the application of a minor the department shall cancel the safety certificate of that minor and the person or estate of that person who signed the application of such minor shall be relieved from liability imposed by this chapter e a restricted junior boating license shall be issued to any minor under fourteen 14 years of age who has fulfilled all of the requirements of this chapter this shall entitle said minor to operate a vessel of 99 horse power or less without an adult present for vessels over 99 horse power an adult someone over the age of eighteen 18 must be on board and is declared the responsible party under no circumstances shall this license allow the operation of a personal water craft pwc upon the waters of the city of maitland unless there is a pwc endorsement the restricted junior boating license may be upgraded to include the operation of a pwc once the operator reaches the age of fourteen 14 provided a practical operations test is also administered and passed f if any person is found to have been convicted of four 4 or more noncriminal infractions or two 2 or more criminal infractions of this chapter or the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder the police department shall suspend such persons motor boat operators safety certificate for a period of not more than one year upon such suspension the certificate holder must surrender to the police department the safety certificate so suspended g the police department shall revoke the motor boat operators safety certificate of any person who 1 operates any motor vessel when such safety certificate or privilege is canceled or suspended  or 2 is found to have violated the provisions of florida statute 32735 and such person shall not be eligible to be recertified for a period of three 3 years from the date of revocation the certificate holder must surrender to the police department the safety certificate so revoked h when any persons safety certificate has been suspended or revoked pursuant to the provisions of this section the police department shall not grant such persons motor boating privileges be restored except upon the reexamination of the certificate holder after the expiration of the period of suspension or revocation so prescribed    12985   32591   72709 reckless or negligent operation generally a powerdriven vessels shall not follow a person on skis kneeboard surfboard tube or similar device at a distance of less than three hundred 300 feet b powerdriven vessels shall stay clear of all vessels at anchor or adrift a minimum of one hundred 100 feet c powerdriven vessels shall stay clear of sailboats sailboards windsurfers canoes kayaks rowboats and all other nonpowerdriven vessels vessels at idle speed vessels powered by electric trolling motors and vessels being used for fishing a minimum of one hundred 100 feet d it shall be unlawful for a vessel operator to permit anyone to ride on the bow gunwales transom outboard motor or swim platform of any vessel under way    32591 state law reference reckless or careless operation fs  32733 overloading a it shall be unlawful to operate a vessel on the waterways of the city containing a number of persons in excess of the manufacturers recommendation or otherwise overloaded to such an extent as to render it unstable or in danger of capsizing or sinking b it shall be unlawful to operate a vessel on the waterways of the city equipped with an engine whose horsepower exceeds the maximum horsepower recommended by the manufacturer of the vessel    32591 speed of vessels a the speed of vessels shall not exceed forty 40 miles per hour during daylight hours or twenty 20 miles per hour between sunset and sunrise b no person shall operate a vessel at speeds which will cause a wake bow or stern wave or propeller wash within one hundred 100 feet of piers boathouses or the shoreline of any lake in the city c all steams streams and canals in the city are hereby declared no wake zones vessel operators shall not proceed at such speed that a wake bow or stern wave or propeller wash is created by their vessel in streams or canals  12985   32591 editors note  adopted dec 9 198 provided for the repeal of  11621164 concerning boating speed near shore or other boats and in canals as derived from  522 and added similar provisions as set out in  1162 above secs 1163 1164  reserved note see the editors note to  1162 reserved editors note  adopted feb 18 198 provided for the repeal of  1165 which limited the maximum horsepower of boat motors used on lake jackson such section was derived from the 1971  anchoring obstructing passage no person shall anchor any boat in such a position as to interfere with the access to or passage canal connecting lakes or bodies of water or in any restricted channels  reserved editors note of adopted mar 25 199 repealed former  1167 which pertained to the rules governing the passing of boats and derived from  vessels meeting in canals a whenever vessels proceeding in opposite directions must pass within a canal in a constricted area the vessel nearest a passing area shall return to that area to effect the passing and when practicable shall pass port to port vessels intending entrance to a canal shall yield the rightofway to boats exiting the canal in the event there is a passing area closer than the exit the boat in the canal shall return or remain in that area to effect the passing b vessels proceeding in the same direction shall not pass in canals c vessels shall not be anchored moored or secured in any manner within any canal or under bridges except in an emergency in which case the police department shall be notified as soon as possible of the location of the vessel nothing herein shall limit the use of piers or boathouses within canals by authorized vessels provided such use does not impede vessels transiting canal    32591 secs 1169 1170  reserved editors note of adopted mar 25 199 repealed former  1169 and 1170 which pertained to the speed of motorboats near unpowered craft and fishing boats and derived from  and 512   reserved editors note  dec 9 198 provided for the repeal of  11701 1171 and 1172 concerning required safety equipment lights life preservers and fire extinguishers as derived from  513 514  and  adopted mar 23 1981  and enacted similar provisions codified as  1171 required equipment a safety equipment and lighting every vessel on the lakes or waterways of the city shall carry safety equipment and conform to uniform lighting requirements in accordance with the current us coast guard safety and lighting requirements and federal regulation unless expressly exempt by state law b white lights required for certain vessels every vessel not under power whether at anchor or adrift and all vessels propelled by trolling motors oars paddles or sails and all other vessels not displaying lights required by the us coast guard minimum requirements for motorboats shall display one white light visible from all directions from three hundred sixty 360 degrees at all times between sunset and sunrise c muffling device every powerdriven vessel shall have a muffling device so constructed and used as to muffle the noise of the exhaust so that it does not exceed a maximum sound level of ninety 90 dba at a distance of fifty 50 feet from the vessel d sound signal every vessel shall have a sound signal capable of a foursecond to sixsecond blast audible for onehalf 12 mile  12985   32591 state law reference boating equipment required fs  32750 reserved note see the editors note following  11701 damage to markers buoys etc  reports of accidents and obstructions it shall be unlawful for any person to remove damage or destroy any channel markers buoys speed limit signs or directional signals maintained by the city in or about any of the lakes or canals within the corporate limits of the city any person injuring or damaging any channel markers buoys bulkheads docks or boathouses or involved in any collision or upset with any other craft shall report such incident to the city police department without delay any person having knowledge of any underwater obstruction or floating object which would endanger the safe navigation of any boat will report the location and nature of such obstruction to the city police department as soon as possible  state law reference mooring to or damaging markers buoys etc fs  32742 use of motorized craft restricted on lake lucien biological data shows that lake lucien is the highestquality lake within the city in order to protect and preserve the high quality of water in lake lucien and in order to promote the public health safety and welfare the following regulations shall apply it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to operate or otherwise use any motorized craft or motordriven boat on lake lucien with the single exception of electrically powered trolling motors that have a maximum thrust capability not exceeding thirtythree 33 pounds nothing herein contained however shall be construed so as to prohibit the use of motorized or motordriven craft on lake lucien by the appropriate governmental agencies or their authorized representatives in carrying out biological hydrological or similar research duties on lake lucien  nor shall this section be construed so as to prohibit the use of any motorized or motordriven craft on lake lucien by any person or persons in response to an emergency  102681 reserved editors note  adopted  repealed former section 1175 in its entirety which pertained to the display of house numbers on boathouses and docks and derived from  12985 enforcement the city police department shall have the power to enforce the regulations contained in this chapter  32591 reserved editors note  adopted  repealed former section 1177 in its entirety which pertained to severability and derived from  adopted  division 4  construction of boat docks boathouses boat ramps boardwalks and seawalls permit required a any person desiring to construct a boat dock boathouse boat ramp boardwalk or seawall within the city of maitland on all natural and artificial including cityowned bodies of water shall first apply for a city of maitland waterfront structure permit prior to the installation no boat dock floating or stationary boathouse boat ramp boardwalk boat slip seawall or other structure shall be constructed except in accordance with an approved permit issued pursuant to this chapter b this division is intended for all waterfront structures it is the intent of this chapter to ensure that on canalfront lots lakefront lots and streamfront lots no boating hazards will be created water pollution from stormwater runoff and other sources will be minimized views of water from adjoining properties will not be unduly impaired and the appearance of the shore when viewed from the water will be kept as natural as reasonably possible the citys lakes canals and streams are among the citys greatest assets and it is in the public interest to require that their aesthetic appeal and water quality be maintained and enhanced when possible c application shall be made to the city in a format approved by the city a processing fee in an amount which shall be determined from time to time by city council shall be paid at the time the application is submitted for review payment of the application fee shall in no way guarantee issuance of a permit and such fee is nonrefundable  72301   81009 application for permit application forms for a permit shall be except for docks or related structures approved for public use no permit application will be accepted unless a principal use exists on the applicants property along with the waterfront structure not exceed two 2 feet above existing grade the maximum boathouse height shall not exceed thirteen 13 feet above the lake elevation nhwe listed in table no 1 in section 1180 and the roof must be pitched the minimums and maximums in this subsection shall apply unless otherwise approved as part of a planned development or developers agreement with the city or by city council on appeal 5 the terminal platform of any boathouse boat dock boat slip boardwalk not including the main access walkway or any other structure permitted under this ordinance shall not exceed eight hundred 800 square feet in total area and shall have no enclosed areas the maximum width of the terminal platform see definition shall not exceed thirty 30 feet unless otherwise approved as part of a planned development or developers agreement with the city or by city council on appeal 6 except for seawalls the natural shoreline must not be changed in the construction of any waterfront structure no soil or sediments shall be allowed to enter any waterway from adjacent upland areas and no sediments within a water body which are disturbed in the process of constructing waterfront structures shall be allowed outside of the approved containment area as indicated on the permit floating turbidity barriers and upland erosion controls are required for all waterfront construction projects and must be installed and approved prior to any other activity including any site preparation or demolition 7 the maximum width of the landward portion of any structure permitted under this division shall not exceed seventytwo 72 inches a minimum width of fortyfour 44 inches shall be required for the waterward portion of any structure except that a minimum width of seventeen 17 inches shall be required for any secondary access around boathouses or boat slips boards used to construct the surface of the structure whether landward or waterward shall not exceed eight 8 inches in width and shall be spaced at least onequarter 14 inch apart 8 no person shall install an electrical device in a waterfront structure without first obtaining an electrical permit in conjunction with the waterfront structure permit 9 an existing seawalls vertical height shall not exceed the 100year flood elevation listed in table 1 no seawall shall be built on the lake side of the nhwe listed in table 1 all seawalls shall be required to have a permit from the department of environmental protection dep prior to application for a city of maitland waterfront structure permit existing seawalls requiring maintenance and repair shall be faced with riprap for stabilization and prevention of undercutting and erosion new vertical seawalls are prohibited except along canals or stream banks that do not allow sufficient area for sloped seawalls sloped riprap type structures or geotube type structures that allow wave energy to dissipate and allow shoreline vegetation to propagate may be permitted 10 permit applications will be reviewed by the city manager or designee for the following a possible obstruction to navigability  b hazard or safety condition  and c unreasonable interference with the riparian or littoral rights of other property owners unreasonable interference shall include but not be limited to 1 proximity of docks of abutting property owners  2 access for boaters and swimmers  and 3 any unusual configuration of the shoreline which would cause the proposed dock to restrict access to sections of the waterway or impairment of lakeview visibility from living areas of abutting properties 11 upon receiving the application the city manager or designee will send notices to the record owners of the five properties to each side of the applicant along the shoreline of the waterbody where the proposed construction is to occur by certified mail return receipt requested 12 after the city manager or designee has conducted an onsite inspection and after all regulations for issuance of a permit have been satisfied as outlined in this chapter the city manager or designee shall approve deny or approve the permit with conditions the decision shall be in writing and shall indicate the date of the decision the applicant will be notified and copies will be sent via certified mail to those property owners required to be notified in subsection 11 above 13 plan revisions must be submitted pursuant to section 1180 including renotification under 118011 14 house numbers shall be prominently displayed on all waterfront structures see definitions  72301   81009 appeals from decisions of the city manager or designee 1 appeal process for adversely affected property owners any person may file a written objection with the city manager within fifteen 15 calendar days of the date on which the city mailed the notices referred to in section 118011 if no such notice of appeal is received within the fifteenday period then the ruling of reviewing staff shall be final if an appeal is filed such appeal shall be heard by the city council at their next available regular meeting notice of the appeal will be provided to the applicant nearby property owners entitled to notification under section 118011 and to persons who have objected in writing to the proposed structure at an advertised public hearing the city council may affirm reverse or modify the decision of the reviewing staff a copy of the decision of the city council will be sent via certified mail to the applicant and those who filed written objections to the permit 2 appeal process for applicants if the city manager or designee either denies a permit or approves a permit with conditions the applicant may appeal the adverse decision or the conditions placed on the permit by sending a letter requesting an appeal to the city clerk within fifteen 15 calendar days on which the city mailed the notices referred to in section 118012 if no such notice of appeal is received within the fifteenday period then the ruling of reviewing staff shall be final if an appeal is filed such appeal shall be heard by the city council at their next available regular meeting notice of the appeal will be provided to the applicant nearby property owners entitled to notification under section 118011 and to persons who have objected in writing to the proposed structure at an advertised public hearing the city council may affirm reverse or modify the decision of the reviewing staff a copy of the decision of the city council will be sent via certified mail to the applicant and those who filed written objections to the permit  72301   81009 nonconforming structures where a structure exists prior to the adoption of this is not in compliance with the terms of this such structure shall be treated as a legal nonconforming structure subject to the following provisions 1 no such nonconforming structure may be enlarged in a way which increases its nonconformity but any structure or portion thereof may be maintained or altered to decrease or maintain its nonconformity 2 minor repairs to the routine maintenance of nonconforming structures are permitted and encouraged routine repairs and maintenance of nonconforming structures or fixtures wiring or plumbing or the repair or replacement of walls shall be permitted nothing in this code shall be deemed to prevent the strengthening or restoring to a safe condition of any structure or part thereof declared to be unsafe by any public official charged with protecting the public safety upon order of such official 3 should such nonconforming structure or nonconforming portion of structure be destroyed by any means to an extent of more than seventyfive 75 percent of the assessed value of the total structure the nonconforming structure or nonconforming portion of the structure shall not be reconstructed except in conformity with the provisions of this a new waterfront structure  and 4 should such structure be moved or relocated for any reason for any distance what so ever it shall thereafter conform to the requirements of this a new waterfront structure  72301   81009 reserved editors note  adopted aug 10 200 repealed former  1183 in its entirety which pertained to the scope and effects of permits issued under this division and derived from  adopted  public hazards 1 structures shall be deemed a public hazard when the lakes management coordinator and a building department designee from the city has determined that said structure has fallen into disrepair a written notification from the city of maitland will be sent to the owner giving the owner sixty 60 days to remedy the hazard or to provide a signed contract for removal or repair to be completed within 90 days of notification or to document a good faith effort to remedy the hazard in a timely manner with an explanation in writing as to why the hazard has not been remedied such explanation must be acceptable to both the lakes management coordinator and to the building official or designee 2 vessels that have sunk below operable depth shall be removed or refloated by the vessels owner within fifteen 15 days of the owners receipt of written notification from the city of maitland instructing the owner to remove or refloat the vessel fuel and oil within the vessel shall be removed from the vessel by the vessels owner within twentyfour 24 hours after receipt and notification from the city  81009 definitions these definitions are to be utilized for maitland city division 4 only access walkway means that portion of the dock that commences on the upland parcel and terminates at the junction with the terminal platform boat dock or dock means any temporary permanently fixed or floating structure extending from the normal high water elevation nhwe into or over the water capable of use for vessel mooring and other waterdependent recreational activities this includes any floating structure boat lift or mooring pilings detached from the land capable of use for mooring vessels and or for other waterdependent activities this also includes any area adjacent to the dock designated for mooring purposes boardwalk elevated walkway structure typically constructed with timber boathouse roofed structure primarily over water used to shelter boats andor watercraft boat ramp means any structure or clearing that extends to or waterward of the normal high water elevation or any structure or clearing upon which trailerable watercraft can be launched or retrieved provided however that notwithstanding the foregoing this definition shall not apply to a homeowner who clears land which is the site of his personal residence in compliance with applicable regulations without building any structure or dredging or filling for the purpose of launching and retrieving his or her personal watercraft boat shelter same as boathouse boat slip area of the dock designed to enclose the boat on three 3 sides disrepair state of being in need of repair enclosed areas an area containing one or more walls or partitions constructed of any material geo tube specially fabricated containers made of highstrength woven geotextile with special high strength seaming to resist pressures during pumping operations reclaiming lake bottom materials used as integral components in the construction of a variety of marine and hydraulic structures living purposes a space in a structure for living sleeping eating cooking andor bathrooms main access walkway primary access to the boathouse or boat dock means that portion of the dock which commences on the upland parcel and terminates at the junction with the terminal platform normal high water elevation means the average elevation of the landward edge of waters over a nineteenyear period as listed in table 1 herein for shorter periods of observation mean high water means the height of the high waters after corrections are applied to eliminate known variations and to reduce the result to the equivalent of a mean 19year value state law reference florida statutes coastal mapping act permit or waterfront structure permit means the waterfront structure permit issued by the city of maitland which includes the placard and set of plans authorizing construction of a boat dock boathouse boat ramp boardwalk or seawall within the city of maitlands natural and artificial bodies of water permit application package means the completed package including the permit application plans fees and detailed specifications submitted to the city of maitland for review and approval principal use means a use of the upland parcel for residential or governmental purpose at a minimum a principal use shall be established by the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for a principal structure retaining wall a manmade structure built of materials such as but not limited to large stones cement rubble railroad ties cement blocks or wooden planks that form a wall to hold upland soil in place preventing its erosion into a water body it is built landward of a surface waters normal high water elevation and the wetland delineation line established by the florida department of environmental protection riprap broken rock cobbles or boulders placed in front of seawalls to slow down wave action and reduce the waves energy being carried shoreward seawall a manmade structure made of materials such as but not limited to cement block concrete galvanized steel wood or metal that is located between the 100year flood elevation and nhwe of a water body the structure is designed and placed such that it prevents shoreline erosion by dispersing the energy of a waves action elsewhere on the shoreline secondary access secondary means of accessing boat andor secondary area to tie up a boat structure that which is built constructed erected or placed including all temporary fixed or movable construction sunk submerged below usable depth for vessel operation terminal platform means that portion of a dock beginning at the terminal end of the main access walkway including platform decking boathouse boat slip and secondary access the terminal platform shall be designed for the mooring and launching of vessels or other waterdependent activities waterfront structure any seawall  retaining wall  boardwalk  boat slip  boat ramp  boathouse  boat dock floating structure  boat lift  or mooring pilings whether temporary or permanent located within a shoreline protection area that area beginning 15 feet landward of the nhwe and extending littoral zone of the waterbody waterway or water body lakes herein set out parks and recreation impact fee the city council hereby establishes a parks and recreation impact fee schedule of two thousand one hundred fiftyone dollars $2151 per single family dwelling unit  and two thousand one hundred fiftyone dollars $2151 per multifamily dwelling unit to offset a portion of the costs associated with providing new park land and facilities for new 7580 et seq authority this article is adopted pursuant to the local government comprehensive planning and land development regulation act florida statutes  12880   62386   7990   61091   32700 purpose and intent a it is hereby declared that the purpose and intent of this article is to preserve and enhance present advantages  encourage the most appropriate use of land water and resources consistent with the public interest  overcome present handicaps  and deal effectively with future development of land within the citys jurisdiction b it is further the intent of this article and the city comprehensive development plan to preserve protect promote and improve the public health safety comfort good order appearance law enforcement fire prevention and general welfare  facilitate the adequate and efficient provision of transportation water sewerage schools parks recreational facilities housing and other requirements and services  and conserve develop utilize and protect the natural resources within the citys jurisdiction  3 12880 what constitutes comprehensive development plan the citys comprehensive development plan shall consist of one volume entitled 20012020 maitland comprehensive development plan dated   12880   62386   7990   61091   4802 legal status of comprehensive development plan a after  all development public and private shall be consistent with the applicable elements of the citys comprehensive development plan b after  no regulation or amendment to any regulation shall be adopted by city council without first being found to be in compliance with the applicable elements of the comprehensive development plan  12880   62386   7990   61091   4802 severability of plan if any part of the citys comprehensive development plan should be found by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid such judgment shall not affect or invalidate the remainder of the comprehensive development plan but the effect shall be confined to that part immediately involved in such judgment  12880 reserved editors note  adopted  repealed former section 1218 in its entirety which pertained to repeal of ordinances or regulations in conflict with the citys comprehensive development plan and derived from  adopted jan 28 1980 secs 12191223  reserved editors note of adopted  repealed former  12191223 which pertained to comprehensive development plan amendments and derived from  adopted nov 10 198 and  adopted  secs 12241239  reserved article iii  reserved footnotes  3  editors note of adopted  repealed  1240 and 1241 formerly contained in art iii which pertained to preservation of vested rights and derived from  adopted nov 10 1986 secs 12401250  reserved article iv  reserved footnotes  4  editors note  2 adopted  repealed art iv  12511263 which pertained to road impact fees and derived from  112690   32700 secs 12511280  reserved article v  reserved footnotes  5  editors note  3 adopted  repealed art v  12811290 which pertained to proportionate fairshare program for transportation facilities and derived from  4907 secs 12811290  reserved article vi  mobility fees authority a this article shall be known and may be cited as the city of maitland mobility fee  b the city council has the authority to adopt this article pursuant to of the 1968 florida constitution and chapters 163 and 166 of the florida statutes and the charter of the city of maitland c planning for new multimodal facility improvements needed to serve new growth and development that generate the need for additional improvements and the implementation of these plans comprehensive planning process is a responsibility of the city under seq florida statutes and is in the best interest of the health safety and welfare of the citizens of the city   92616  intent and purpose a this article is intended to impose a mobility fee payable prior to issuance of a building permit in an amount based upon the average amount of new person miles of travel attributable to new development and the average cost of providing the multimodal capacity needed to serve such new travel this article shall not be construed to authorize imposition of fees related to multimodal improvement needs attributable to existing development b this article is intended to allow new development in compliance with the comprehensive development plan to share in the burdens of growth new development shares in this burden by paying a pro rata share of the reasonably anticipated costs of multimodal facilities needed to accommodate the person miles of travel demands created by new development as well as by complying with other appropriate development approval conditions this article is intended to provide flexibility to address the needs of individual developments that because of location timing or other characteristics require different treatment in the form of reduced fees or supplemental requirements c towards this end the mobility fees are replacing road impact fees adopted pursuant to as amended and are based upon the calculation methodology incorporated in the city of maitland mobility fee technical report prepared by nue urban concepts llc dated july 2016   92616  definitions the following terms used in this article shall be defined as follows applicant is the property owner or duly designated agent of the property owner of land on which a building permit or special use permit is requested and a mobility fee is due pursuant to this article autonomous vehicle is a motor vehicle that uses artificial intelligence sensors and global positioning system coordinates to drive itself with or without the active intervention of a human operator bicycle sharing means short term bicycle rental available at unattended stations a bicyclesharing system public bicycle system or bikeshare program is a short term bicycle rental service in which bicycles are made available for shared use to individuals on a very short term basis bike share systems allow people to rent a bicycle at any selfserve bikestation and return it to any other bike station located within the systems service area building permit is an official document or certificate issued by the city authorizing the commencement of construction of any structure or portion of a structure pursuant to the city of maitland zoning as amended and the land development regulations of the city of maitland if no building permit is required for the construction or occupation of a structure then the term shall be deemed to include a special use permit occupancy permit or other form of final city approval for the construction installation or occupancy of a structure capital expenses are defined as the expenditures for multimodal improvements identified in the capital improvements element and capital improvements program and associated stormwater management areas a the repayment of principal and interest or any redemption premium for loans advances bonds bond anticipation notes and any other form of indebtedness then outstanding  b reasonable administrative and overhead expenses necessary or incidental to expanding and improving the transportation facilities  c expenses of planning corridor and alternatives analysis route studies and pond siting analysis reports soil borings tests surveys construction plans and legal and other professional advice or financial analysis relating to transportation facilities including the reimbursement of the city for such expenses incurred before the transportation facilities were approved and adopted into the capital improvement plan  d the acquisition of rightsofway and easements for the transportation facilities including the costs incurred in connection with the exercise of eminent domain  e the clearance and preparation of any transportation facility site including the demolition of structures on the site and relocation of utilities  f floodplain compensation and wetland mitigation  g all expenses incidental to or connected with the issuance sale redemption retirement or purchase of bonds bond anticipation notes or other forms of indebtedness including funding of any reserve redemption or other fund or account provided for in the ordinance or resolution authorizing such bonds notes or other form of indebtedness  and h costs of design and construction including mobilization maintenance of traffic during construction and cei construction engineering and inspection services capital improvement element is the element of the city of maitlands comprehensive development plan as amended annually by the capital improvements program cip which evaluates the need for public facilities as identified in the comprehensive development plan elements and on the mobility plan and as defined in the applicable definition of each public facility estimates the cost of improvements analyzes the fiscal capability of the local government to finance and construct improvements adopts financial policies to guide the funding of improvements and schedules the funding and construction of improvements in a manner necessary to ensure that capital improvements are provided when required based on the needs identified in the comprehensive development plan car sharing is defined as the organized collective use of a dispersed network of shared vehicles available twentyfour 24 hours seven 7 days a week at unattended selfservice locations membership based service and is available to all qualified drivers in a community with no separate written agreement required each time a member reserves and uses a vehicle city is hereby defined as the city of maitland florida city council is hereby defined as the legislative body of the city of maitland commercial uses means those business retail service or professional activities which provide products and services to individuals businesses or groups and which include those uses specified in the ite trip generation manual under land use  community retail shall mean individual freestanding retail uses outside of a retail center or a retail center that are between tenthousand and one 10001 square feet and one hundred thousand 100000 square feet in size and are not otherwise specifically included as a separate and distinct land use in the mobility fee schedule complete streets means a transportation policy and design approach that requires multimodal transportation improvements to be planned designed operated and maintained to enable safe convenient and comfortable travel and access for users of all ages and abilities regardless of their mode of transportation and to allow for safe travel by those walking bicycling or using other forms of nonmotorized travel riding public transportation or driving motor vehicles or low speed electric vehicles separate and defined spaces are provided for the various modes of travel planned within the crosssection comprehensive development plan cdp is defined as the city of maitlands 2030 comprehensive development plan addressing the planning period 2010203 updated september 27 th  2010 adopted as periodically amended in accordance and consistent with state statutes convenience market and gas means any use which sells fuel to the public or membership club and includes land uses with fuel pumps such as but not limited to gas station service station or convenience market fuel positions are the total number of motor vehicles that can fuel at one time with a standard fuel pump typically having two 2 fuel positions an attached restaurant with drivethru shall be assessed a separate mobility fee per the mobility fee schedule county is hereby defined as orange county government design guidelinesstandards are the city of maitlands current any other area specific land development regulations pattern books or guidelines enacted by the city by ordinance that are applicable to the subject development developer is an individual agency or group that submits a development application to the city of maitland or enters into discussion or negotiation with the city of maitland regarding potential development within the city limits development is any construction reconstruction or any use of real property which requires review and approval of a development permit development agreement is an enforceable agreement entered into between the city of maitland and a developer in which specific development terms conditions obligations are defined and agreed upon including agreements entered pursuant to the citys home rule powers under the florida constitution and florida statutes an agreement entered pursuant to or an agreement or development order issued pursuant to florida statutes development order is any order granting with or without conditions or denying a development permit including any building permit zoning permit rezoning subdivision approval site plan approval permitted conditional use certification variance or any official action of the city having the effect of permitting any type level nature density intensity or other form of development of land dwelling unit means a room or rooms connected together constituting a separate independent housekeeping entity for owner occupancy or rental or lease on a daily weekly monthly or longer basis and physically separated from any other rooms or dwelling units which may be in the same structure and containing sleeping and sanitary facilities and one 1 kitchen the term dwelling unit as used in this article shall be deemed to include mobile home dwellings and assisted living facilities where mobility fees are based on the number of beds fdot means the state of florida department of transportation fhwa means the federal highway administration a division of the us dot gross floor area shall mean the sum in square feet of the area of each floor level including cellars basements mezzanines penthouses corridors lobbies stores and offices that are within the principal outside faces of exterior walls not including architectural setbacks or projections included are all areas that have floor surfaces with clear standing head room six 6 feet six 6 inches minimum regardless of their use if a ground level area or part thereof within or adjacent to the principal outside faces of the exterior walls is not enclosed and is determined to be a part of the principal use such as outdoor seating display or storage this gfa is considered part of the overall square footage of the building unroofed areas and unenclosed roofedover spaces which are considered accessory and do not create a demand to the principal use should be excluded from the area calculations for purposes of this article the gfa of any parking garages within the building shall be excluded from the gfa of the entire building impact fee is the payment of money for a proportional share of the cost of transportation facilities needed to serve new growth and development as formerly authorized by the city of maitland road impact fees impact generating land development activity is land development designed or intended to permit a use of the land which will contain more dwelling units andor increase in gross floor area of nonresidential uses than the then existing use of the land in a manner that increases the generation of person trips and person miles of travel demand independent mobility fee study means a study conducted by an entity other than the city to calculate the mobility fee for a particular development the study must be based upon a methodology approved by the city and conducted to professionally acceptable standards by an individual with documented experience with conducting such studies or developing mobility fee and transportation impact fee experience industrial uses shall mean those activities which are predominantly engaged in the assembly finishing processing packaging andor storage of products and which include those uses specified in the ite trip generation manual under land use  but excluding miniwarehouses institutional uses mean those activities which are predominantly engaged in education religious observation and cultural activities or oversight of persons outside and which include those uses specified in the ite trip generation manual under land use  ite trip generation manual shall mean and refer to the latest edition of the report entitled trip generation produced by the institute of transportation engineers ite level of service is a standard used to determine the capacity of multimodal facilities based on the sources referenced in the mobility fee study living area shall mean the sum of the area in square feet of each floor of the dwelling unit measured from the exterior surface of the exterior walls or walls adjoining public spaces such as apartment hallways or the centerline of common walls shared with other dwelling units this square footage does not include garages or unenclosed areas living streets means a multimodal transportation facilities based on the dutch woonerf concept that treats all modes equally with no defined spaces for any mode living streets typically do not have curbs pavement markings traffic control devices parking spaces speed limit signs or have posted speed limits fifteen 15 mph or less mobility fee administrator shall mean the city of maitland official responsible for administration implementation and interpretation of all mobility fee ordinances policies and manuals the public works director or designee shall be responsible for administration of the mobility fee ordinances the public works director or designee shall obtain approval in writing from the city manager for any decisions made under sections 12105 thru 12111 before those decisions can become effective the city council may elect to designate an individual other than the public works director or designee as the mobility fee administrator mobility fee means the fee assessed at the time of issuance of a building permit or special use permit on a proportional basis associated with the average demand for mobility facilities created by the development of a principal use to provide funds for multimodal facilities needed to address demand generated by new development mobility fee benefit district means all areas within the geographic extents of the city established pursuant to section 12112 hereof for the purposes of collecting and expending mobility fees mobility fee technical report means the city of maitland mobility fee technical report dated july 2016 and prepared by nue urban concepts llc and adopted pursuant to section 12103 hereof and which supports the imposition of the mobility fee mobility plan means the mobility plan adopted into the city of maitland 2030 comprehensive development plan which serves as the basis for a mobility fee multifamily apartment shall mean a building containing two 2 or more dwelling units that are not individually owned are for rent or lease and often have common utility meters and includes duplexes triplexes quadraplexes garden style apartments and multistory structures with multiple dwelling units multimodal means multiple modes of travel including but not limited to walking bicycling jogging rollerblading kayaking riding transit driving a golf cart low speed electric vehicle or motor vehicle multimodal facility means capital facilities necessary or convenient for the movement of people from one location to another and includes but is not limited to capital infrastructure such as sidewalks trails paths bike lanes paved shoulders cycle tracks transit stops park and ride lots parking garages transit vehicles car bicycle and ridesharing programs transit pullouts wayfining signs streetscape bicycle racks shelterskiosks benches docks bicycle stations crosswalks roundabouts vehicular travel lanes turnlanes bridges curbs gutters medians andor shoulders drainage facilities andor mitigation areas signage advanced traffic management systems andor traffic control devices multipurpose recreational facility is an indoor andor outdoor entertainment venue where impact is measured by the total acreage of the area used to carry out the principal function of the facility and includes uses such as but not limited to bowling skating gocarts minigolf batting cages bounce houses trampolines dance gymnastics climbing walls and driving ranges and uses not otherwise specified in the mobility fee schedule neighborhood retail shall mean any individual freestanding retail uses outside of a retail center or a retail center that is less than ten thousand 10000 square feet in size and are not otherwise specifically included as a separate and distinct land use in the mobility fee schedule nonresidential uses means the carrying out of industrial entertainment lodging recreational institutional office medical commercial or service activity and which include those uses specified in the ite trip generation manual under land use  300 400 500 600 700 800 and 900 and excludes all uses under ite trip generation manual under land use  office use means the carrying out of a professional or governmental service that does not result in the production manufacturing or sale of a physical object on premise and which include those uses specified in the ite trip generation manual under land use except for medical and dental offices person mile of travel pmt means the number of miles traveled by each person on a trip in order to account for all miles traveled by motor vehicle transit walking andor bicycling person trip means a trip by one 1 person by one 1 or more modes of travel including but not limited to driving a motor vehicle or low speed electric vehicle riding transit walking bicycling or paddling principal use means the carrying out of any building activity or the making of any material change in the use of a structure or land that requires the issuance of a building permit or special use permit and which generates person trips and person miles of travel over and above the existing use of the structure or land recreation uses mean those activities which are predominantly engaged in physical activities recreation sports outdoor activities entertainment and which include those uses specified in the ite trip generation manual under land use  regional retail shall mean any individual freestanding retail use outside of a retail center or a retail center that is greater than one hundred thousand 100000 square feet in size and are not otherwise specifically included as a separate and distinct land use in the mobility fee schedule restaurant with drivethru means a free standing out parcel or inline retail center restaurant establishment that prepares and serves any food or drink for consumption on or offpremise that has one 1 or more drivethru lanes pickup window accessible by motor vehicle or any drivein facilities or driveup facilities where orders are placed while in a motor vehicle residential use means a dwelling unit or dwelling units and shall include those uses specified in the ite trip generation manual under the land use  ride sharing is where than more than one 1 person rides primarily with unrelated persons using carpools vanpools andor a realtime ondemand ride sharing service also known as ridesourcing accessed smartphone application or online portal where onetime shared rides are provided on short notice by private motor vehicles rightofway means land property or interest therein that is necessary to accommodate all of the required elements for and to support the construction andor improvement of multimodal transportation facilities singlefamily detached is a structure that is located on its own lot does not share an exterior wall with another building and contains only one 1 dwelling unit singlefamily attached includes townhomes urban flats villas or condos that are owner occupied or individually owned and share a wall with one 1 or more dwelling units streetscape includes hardscape elements such as pavers benches lighting trash and recycling receptacles fountains seating shade structure landscape elements such as canopy and understory trees shrubs bushes grasses and flowers green infrastructure and architectural structures and projections that provide shade and protection from various weather conditions sit down restaurant means a free standing or out parcel restaurant establishment that prepares and serves food primarily for consumption on premise that does not have drivethru or drivein facilities transportation operation and maintenance expenses means expenses associated with the operation and maintenance of transportation facilities including cleaning repairs mowing landscape maintenance resurfacing that does not expand transportation capacity and fuel and salary costs for the operation of transit systems vehicle miles of travel means a unit to measure vehicle travel made by a private motor vehicle such as an automobile van pickup truck or motorcycle where each mile traveled is counted as one 1 vehicle mile regardless of the number of persons in the vehicle   92616  adoption of mobility fee technical report the mobility fee technical report entitled city of maitland mobility fee technical reportjuly 201 prepared by nue urban concepts llc is hereby adopted this adoption includes but is not limited to the basis of the assumptions conclusions and findings in such study as to the basis of the mobility fee the methodology for calculating the mobility fee the person miles of travel assigned to various land use categories as well as the findings for internal and community capture for the three 3 assessment areas and the basis for the mobility fee benefit district boundary the three assessment areas are 1 community redevelopment area cra 2 mobility tiers 1 and 2 and 3 mobility tier 3 per the comprehensive development plan the study presents the technical analysis and detailed methodology supporting the city of maitland mobility fees consistent with the comprehensive development plan 2030 the study shall be maintained and made available by the city upon request   92616  mobility fee imposition the mobility fee imposed by this article shall apply to new applications for building permits and special use permit applications for a change in use submitted on or after  1 this article shall not be imposed on building permits otherwise necessary for a room additions remodeling rehabilitation or other improvements to an existing structure provided there is no increase in person trips or person miles of travel and no increase in gross floor area for nonresidential uses and no increase in the number of dwelling units for residential uses  or b rebuilding of a damaged or destroyed structure whether voluntary or involuntary provided there is no increase in the intensity of use or no increase in gross floor area for nonresidential uses and no increase in the number of dwelling units for residential uses  or c a change in occupancy that does not generate additional person trips or person miles of travel or any increase in gross floor area for nonresidential uses or increase in the number of dwelling units for residential uses d accessory buildings that do not result in an increase in person trips or person miles of travel will be exempt from the fee eg detached garage sheds parking structures covered parking 2 there is hereby imposed upon all impact generating land development activity as herein defined a mobility fee due at the time of issuance of a building permit or special use permit and no building permit or special use permit shall be issued until said mobility fee shall have been paid except as otherwise herein provided mobility fees are assessed at the mobility fee rate in effect at the time the building permit is issued if the building permit is for less than the entire contemplated development the fee shall be computed for the amount of development covered by the permit the obligations for payment of mobility fees shall run with the land 3 any developer who prior to the effective date for mobility fees paid city road impact fees shall have those amounts applied to the balance due for the current mobility fee for a not previously issued building permit 4 additionally the mobility fee will be imposed for any structure that is altered expanded or replaced that results in an increase in person trips and person miles of travel over the existing land use 5 the mobility fee is calculated on the basis of the person miles of travel generated from the land use if the pmt increases due to a change in size or use the fee due shall be the incremental difference resulting from the alteration expansion or replacement as determined by the mobility fee schedule less the fee that would be imposed under the applicable rate prior to the alteration expansion or replacement 6 in the event that there is a change in use that results in a decrease in person miles of travel generated by the previously allowed use the applicant shall not be entitled to a refund or credit 7 any person who shall initiate any new impact generating land development activity shall except as otherwise provided for herein pay a mobility fee as set forth in the following mobility fee schedule mobility fee schedule
