article i  in general obstructing generally no person shall block or in any manner obstruct any street alley or sidewalk by placing anything therein or thereon or by using such street alley or sidewalk for any purpose which might inconvenience or injure passersby no one shall place or deposit or permit to be placed or deposited or to remain in front of his place of business or property any article of any description which blocks or tends to block the sidewalk alley street or other public rightofway from ready access by the public  obstructing by vendors from vehicles no person engaged in the business of selling and vending goods wares and merchandise from any vehicle truck cart or wagon using the streets and sidewalks of the city shall obstruct the streets and sidewalks with such vehicle truck car or wagon by parking or stopping such vehicle truck cart or wagon for the purpose of carrying on the sale of goods wares and merchandise for a period of time longer than five 5 minutes at any location  obstructing sidewalks by congregating it shall be unlawful for any person to stand or gather upon any sidewalk in the city in such a manner as to obstruct the passage of persons along such sidewalk  duty to remove obstructions it shall be unlawful for any person who places any obstruction as aforesaid in any street lane alley or way or on any sidewalk to fail or refuse to remove the same within a reasonable time after being notified by the city police  or having removed such obstructions to replace the same or a similar obstruction  excavating or doing work affecting public ways  registration bond required it shall be the duty of every contractor or other person or entity who shall receive permission from the city to open excavate engage in construction or employ construction devices in any form or manner in on over upon or under any portion of the streets ways sidewalks alleys or any other public rightsofway within the city to register his name with the director of public works in a book provided for that purpose giving his full name residence and place of business and in case of removal of residence from one place to another in the city to have made corresponding changes in said registry accordingly  and it shall be the further duty of every such person or entity to give good and sufficient bond in the sum of five thousand dollars $500000 to be approved by the city legal counsel conditioned to save the city harmless from all loss cost debt damage expense and any and all other injury resulting in any way either directly or indirectly from the aforementioned excavating opening engaging in construction or employing construction devices  provided however that in lieu of the said bond such person or entity may provide liability insurance satisfactory to the city in such form as to directly protect the city from all actions at law and proceedings in equity with coverage equal to or greater than the amount of said bond  railways to pave and maintain crossings whenever or wherever the city or the owners of abutting property on any street shall pave or shall cause to be paved any street or part of a street on which any railroad tracks are located the person operating such railroad tracks shall at the same time or upon notice in writing given by the city and under its supervision and direction pave the spaces between its rails and the spaces between its tracks and at least two 2 feet beyond the ends of the ties in the same manner and with the same material as is used in paving the remainder of the street or with some material satisfactory to the city manager and shall maintain the same in good order and condition in the event any person operating such railroad tracks shall fail to do such paving or maintaining within thirty 30 days after such notice the city may do the same  and the expense thereof shall be paid by the person operating such tracks and shall be secured by a lien against the railroad tracks  access permits for connections to roads in state highway system any person firm or entity including a governmental entity other than the city of maitland seeking to connect alter or improve access to the state highway system within the city of maitland must first apply for and receive an access permit from the city such access permit shall be in addition to any permit required by the florida department of transportation dot as a prerequisite to connection to the state highway system and receipt of an access permit from the city neither relieves the recipient from the necessity to obtain a permit from dot nor guarantees the right to connect to the state highway system application for access permits shall be processed in the following manner 1 any person firm or entity including a governmental entity other than the city of maitland seeking to connect alter or improve access to any portion of the state highway system within the city must first file an application for access permit such application shall at a minimum include the name and address of the person firm or entity seeking to connect alter or improve access  the street address or legal description of the parcel of land on which the improvement is proposed to be placed as well as a statement of all persons owning any legal or beneficial rights in such land  a statement as to what type of vehicular use the improvement will be put including estimates of average and peak vehicle trips per day over such improvement an assessment of the resulting effects on the level of service for the roadway and the two 2 closest intersections and the increase if any to average or peak hour vehicle trips per day over the road to which the improvement gives access  a statement as to what construction materials will be used in the improvement including an estimate of the duration of such construction  and a scale sketch of the proposed improvement when completed accurately depicting dimensions elevations grade angle of intersection with rightofway and any curbs gutters sidewalks gates existing and proposed signals and traffic control signage or other associated improvements for the purpose of administering this section the word improvements shall mean any construction activity undertaken upon or adjacent to any roadway which is a part of the state highway system within the city of maitland whether or not publicly dedicated for any purpose related to widening or repairing existing access this definition is intended to include all improvements of every kind to roadways and adjacent real property which could in any way affect traffic volumes on the state highway system within the city and should be read broadly so as to effectuate that intent 2 the application shall be accompanied by payment to the city of an application fee of one hundred dollars $10000 until this fee has been paid no action shall be taken on any application 3 following submission of the application for access permit the director of public works director shall have a period of not more than ninety 90 days for staff review of the proposed connection should the department of public works the department determine that a longer review period is required to thoroughly assess the probable impact of the proposed connection upon the city the director shall notify the applicant at least fourteen 14 business days before the expiration of the aforementioned ninetyday period that extended review will be necessary the department shall evaluate the proposed connection in light of its probable effects upon the state highway system traffic flow and vehicular congestion public safety quality of life and the natural environment within the city 4 the following are hereby adopted as minimum standards for the department to use in evaluating access permit applications and the department is hereby authorized to adopt such further standards as it finds necessary to achieve the ends expressed in subsections 2 of this section a the standards contained in the comprehensive plan for the city of maitland  b the standards contained in the dot manual policy and guidelines for vehicular connections to the state highway system  c the standards contained in florida administrative j for measuring traffic volume  specifically level of service as defined in fac rule 9j3e and peak hour vehicle trips by which such levels of service are computed the department shall deny a permit for any improvement which the department estimates will result in either 1 a ten per cent 10% or greater increase in average or peak vehicle trips per day  or 2 reduction of the level of service of the roadway to which an applicant desires to make an improvement 5 if the director finds that the proposed access will meet the requirements of this section he shall issue a permit therefor the director is hereby authorized and empowered to revoke any permit issued by him pursuant to this section upon the failure of the holder thereof to comply with any provision of this section any decision or action made or taken by the director pursuant to this section may be appealed in writing to the city council within thirty 30 days after any such decision or action 6 this section shall be enforced and violations hereof shall be punished as provided by law  5889 secs 1581516  reserved article ii  sidewalks and curbs division 1  generally permit required for work relating to sidewalks a permit from the city shall be required for the construction reconstruction maintenance or repair of any sidewalk in the city  sidewalk specifications except as is otherwise provided herein all sidewalks constructed or repaired in the city shall conform to the specifications and requirements for sidewalks in new subdivisions cross reference requirements for sidewalks in new subdivisions  1662 sidewalk width in business or commercial areas sidewalks shall be not less than six 6 feet wide in areas predominantly business or commercial in nature or to the extent of available rightofway  sidewalks to be constructed when buildings built in all districts on lots and parcels having no sidewalks sidewalks shall be constructed along streets and in the public rightofway by all persons or parties obtaining building permits for structures used for human habitation or the conduct of business or commercial activity to be built on lots adjacent to such streets    32700 condemnation removal of nonconforming or dangerous sidewalks the city council may condemn and order removed any sidewalk in the city which is not built in accordance with specified plans specifications and materials or which is a public safety hazard in case of the refusal or neglect of the property owner of the abutting property to remove or remedy such sidewalk after notice served as provided by section 1523 the city council shall have such sidewalk removed and the costs of such removal assessed against such abutting property owner  council may require sidewalk construction by owner property owners may be required by the city council to construct sidewalks on any street abutting their property within a time limit specified by the council  notice of sidewalk condemnation or requiring construction the notice required by section 1521 hereof and notice requiring a property owner to construct a sidewalk as provided by section 1522 shall direct the abutting property owner to forthwith commence and within thirty 30 days after date of such notice complete the construction reconstruction or repair work the city clerk shall mail such notice to the address of each such property owner if the address is known or by reasonable diligence can be obtained by the clerk  if the address is unknown or cannot be obtained by reasonable diligence or if such notice is returned unclaimed then a copy of such notice directed to the owner shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the county once each week for two 2 consecutive weeks two publications being sufficient directing the owner to forthwith commence and within thirty 30 days after the last publication of such notice or within such other time as the council may direct complete the construction reconstruction or repair work  failure of owner to comply with notice  work to be done by city  assessment of costs in the event the abutting property owner shall fail or refuse to do and perform the construction reconstruction or repair work on any sidewalk or proposed sidewalk within the time prescribed in the notice under the provisions of section 1523 hereof then the city council shall do or cause such work to be done and assess the cost thereof as a charge and lien against such property of the same extent and character as the lien granted to the city by law for special assessments for the cost of local improvements  secs 15251534  reserved division 2  crossing other than at driveways permit required no person shall operate any vehicle of any kind or character on or over any sidewalk or curb within the city except at such places as driveways exist without first obtaining a written permit and making the deposit provided for in the following sections  application for permit in case any person desires to operate any vehicle on or over any sidewalk or curb at any place except at a driveway he shall make application to the building official therefor said application shall specify the place involved the duration of time for which such permit is desired and the kind or kinds of vehicles desired to be operated on or over the place specified said permit shall be accompanied with a fee of one hundred dollars $10000 and shall not be valid for a period of longer than sixty 60 days  deposit required  permit issuance upon the application being filed and the fee being paid the building official shall make a determination as to the reasonable cost of replacing or repairing such curb or sidewalk over which operation is proposed to be permitted the amount determined shall be deposited with the director of finance and thereupon the building official shall issue a permit allowing such crossing by such vehicle  return of deposit on application of permittee the director of finance shall retain the sum so deposited until the time called for in the permit shall have expired after said time the permit holder may apply to the director of finance for a refund of said deposit upon such application the building official shall inspect the sidewalk and curb over which the permit allowed vehicular operation to ascertain if the same has been damaged destroyed or broken in the event it is found that the sidewalk or curb has not been damaged destroyed or broken the deposit shall be returned to said permit holder in the event the sidewalk or curb has been destroyed or damaged the building official shall cause said destruction or damage to be remedied and if after so doing any of said deposit remains after paying for such replacement or repair then the part remaining shall be returned to the permit holder  return of deposit without application of permittee if the time provided in the permit has expired and the permit holder has not within two 2 weeks after the expiration thereof applied to the director of finance for a refund as herein provided then it shall be the duty of the building official as soon as reasonably possible to inspect the sidewalk and curb involved and in the event said sidewalk and curb has not been damaged or destroyed the director of finance shall then return said deposit to the permit holder at his last known mailing address in the event the sidewalk or curb has been damaged or destroyed the building official will cause the damage or destruction to be remedied and if after so doing any of said deposit remains after paying for such replacement or repair then the part thereof remaining shall be mailed to the permit holder at his last known mailing address  subdivisions footnotes  1  cross reference flood hazard prevention standards for subdivisions  579  fire protection facilities and services impact fee  651 et seq  flood damage prevention ch 65  land development regulations ch 75  subdivision process  7590 et seq  planning and development generally ch 12  road impact fee  1251 et seq  streets and sidewalks generally ch 15  water and sewers generally ch 20  zoning ch 21 article i  in general purpose and intent land subdivision is the first step in community development once land has been subdivided into streets lots and blocks and publicly recorded the correction of defects is costly and difficult subdivided land sooner or later becomes a public responsibility in that roads drainage and utilities must be maintained and various customary municipal services must be provided the welfare of the entire city is directly affected by land subdivision it is to the interest of all taxpayers and citizens the developer and future residents that subdivisions be conceived designed and developed in accordance with sound practice and appropriate standards the intent and purpose of these regulations is to provide for the harmonious development of the city  to secure a coordinated layout and adequate provision for traffic  and to secure adequate provision for light air recreation transportation potable water flood prevention drainage sewers other sanitary facilities and city services in addition to the minimum requirements for construction of such improvements as roads and drainage compliance with the intent of these regulations requires that good design be practiced in subdivision planning valuable and scenic natural features conserved and adequate open space be made available for public use subdivision design should be adapted to the peculiarities and opportunities of the site should utilize contemporary imaginative design and should avoid monotonous repetition of a wasteful pattern of gridiron layouts and long straight minor or collector streets size shape and orientation of lots and blocks should be carefully considered with relation to future use of the various lots to be created it is intended that this chapter shall be construed liberally in the favor of the city  jurisdiction the regulations herein set out shall apply to all lands presently within the limits of the city and to any lands which may in the future be annexed to and be made a part of the city no land shall be subdivided unless such subdivision conforms to the provisions of this chapter  applicability a in order to subdivide land and file a plat thereon except merely to record the boundaries of an ownership all requirements as set out in this chapter shall be met and the procedures as herein set forth shall be followed b notwithstanding the provisions of section 16423 the sale or exchange of small parcels of land to or between adjoining property owners where such sale or exchange does not create additional lots shall not be considered a subdivision of land    32700 definitions for the purpose of this chapter certain words or terms used herein shall be interpreted as follows 1 administrative official an official designated by the city manager who shall be charged with the responsibility for the enforcement and administration of these regulations 2 alleys a rightofway providing a secondary means of access and service to abutting property 3 buildings the word building includes the word structure and shall be construed as if followed by the phrase or part thereof 4 culdesac a street terminated at the end by a vehicular turnaround 5 dedication a generic term used as a surrogate for or in reference to easements 6 developer a person or his agent who undertakes the activities covered by these regulations particularly the preparation and presentation of a subdivision plat showing the layout of the land and the improvements involved thereon inasmuch as the subdivision plat is merely a necessary means to the end of assuring a satisfactory development the term developer includes the term subdivider even though the identity or persons involved in successive stages of the project may vary 7 easement any strip of land created by a subdivider for public or private utilities drainage sanitation or other specified uses having limitations the title to which shall remain in the name of the property owner subject to the right of use designated in the reservation of the servitude the granting of such an easement will be an express grant which may or may not be recorded in any case the public when benefited by the easement will be known as the dominant estate and the property which is subject to the easement will be known as the servient estate the easement runs with the land and the dominant estate will have full rights to use the easement for the stated purpose and full rights to permit or deny use of the easement to any other party including the servient estate for any purpose whatsoever 8 engineer refers to a registered professional engineer licensed in florida and qualified to perform duties for a developer under the terms of these regulations 9 half or partial street a street generally parallel and adjacent to the boundary line of a tract which is only a portion of the ultimate rightofway width 10 improvements public public improvements may include but are not limited to street pavements curbs and gutters sidewalks alley pavements walkway pavements water mains sanitary sewers storm sewers or drains street names signs landscaping permanent reference monuments permanent control points monuments or any other improvement required by the city council 11 land the word land includes water surface and land under water 12 lot lot includes tract or parcel and means the least fractional part of subdivided lands having limited fixed boundaries and an assigned number letter or other name it may be identified a lot must be of sufficient size to meet the minimum requirements of chapter 21 as to use coverage and area and to provide such yard and open spaces as are required by chapter 21 13 lot depth as defined by the city zoning code 14 lot width as defined by the city zoning code 15 plat a map or delineated representation of the subdivision of lands being a complete exact representation of the subdivision and other information in compliance with the requirements of all applicable sections of fs   and of this chapter such plat shall depict such facilities and public improvements as may be required under this chapter 16 rightofway land dedicated deeded used or to be used for a street alley walkway boulevard drainage facility access for ingress and egress or other purpose by the public certain designated individuals or governing bodies 17 sight distance the maximum extent of unobstructed vision in a horizontal plane along a street located at any given point on the street 18 street a way for vehicular traffic whether designated as a street highway thoroughfare parkway throughway road avenue boulevard lane place or however otherwise designated 19 street collector a street which in addition to giving access to abutting properties carries traffic from minor streets to the major system of arterial streets and highways including the principal entrance street or streets of a residential development and streets for circulation within a development 20 street major arterial a street or highway used primarily for fast and heavy traffic traveling considerable distances with a width of rightofway of one hundred and six 106 feet or more 21 street marginal access a minor street parallel to and adjacent to arterial streets or highways and which provides access to abutting property and protection from a marginal access street may also be called a frontage road 22 street minor a street used primarily for access to abutting properties and not for 23 subdivision the division of land into three or more lots parcels tracts tiers blocks sites or units or any other division of land the term includes establishment of new streets and alleys additions and resubdivisions  and when appropriate to the context relates to the process of subdividing or to the lands or area subdivided 24 surveyor refers to a land surveyor registered in florida and engaged by the developer to survey and prepare the plat of the land proposed for subdivision 25 used the words used or occupied include the words intended designed or arranged to be used or occupied 26 walkway a rightofway intended primarily for pedestrians excluding selfpropelled vehicles 27 work shall include all construction shown or required on the plat as approved as well as all required construction as shown on approved plans and specifications for all facilities and features of any kind    32700 procedure for amendments this chapter may be amended from time to time by the city council but no amendment shall become effective unless it shall have been proposed by or shall have been submitted to the planning and zoning commission for review and recommendation the planning and zoning commission shall have thirty 30 days within which to submit its report if the planning and zoning commission fails to submit a report within the specified time it shall be deemed to have approved the amendment  modifications for largescale developments a authorized the standards and requirements of these regulations may be modified by the planning and zoning commission in the case of a plan and program for a new town a complete community or a neighborhood unit which in the judgment of the planning and zoning commission provided adequate public spaces and improvements for the circulation recreation light air and service needs of the tract when fully developed and populated which will provide such covenants or other legal provisions as will insure conformity to and achievement of the city plan for development and which will insure that such development will not constitute an economic and tax burden on the city b conditions in granting modifications the planning and zoning commission may require such conditions as will in its judgment secure substantially the objectives of the standards and requirements so modified  conflicting regulations whenever any provisions of this chapter impose more stringent requirements regulations restrictions or limitations than are imposed or required by the provisions of any other law ordinance regulation or restrictive covenant then the provisions of this chapter shall govern whenever any provisions of any ordinance law regulation or restrictive covenant are more restrictive than this chapter then such ordinance regulation law or restrictive covenant shall govern  administration and enforcement the city manager shall administer and enforce this subdivision code violations penalties and enforcement procedures shall be as set forth in of this ordinances  additional standards and regulations authorized in addition to the standards set out in these regulations the city manager is empowered to prescribe additional standards and specifications governing the installation of water and sewer lines the drainage of streets and adjacent areas the installation of curbs gutters and sidewalks and the grading and paving of streets such standards and specifications shall after recommendation of the planning and zoning commission and approval by the city council have the same force and effect as if recited in detail in this chapter  secs 16101613  reserved editors note of adopted  repealed former  16101613 which pertained to a schedule of fees and charges for processing matters pertaining to subdivisions  issuance of building permits prior to final approval of subdivision improvements  selling or buying land by reference to unapproved plats  and approval of an appendix to this chapter the repealed provisions derived from 1 16151 1617 1619  adopted oct 27 1986 secs 16141623  reserved article ii  reserved footnotes  2  editors note of adopted  repealed  16241628 which pertained to plats and plat approval procedures and derived from 9 secs 16241638  reserved article iii  design standards generally the subdividing and development of any area subject to this chapter shall be in conformity with the citys general goals objectives and established city policies and plans  streets a the arrangement character extent width grade and location of all streets shall conform to the general city plan and shall be considered in their relations to existing and planned streets to topographical conditions to public convenience and safety and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets b where such is not shown in the general city plan the arrangement of streets in a subdivision may either provide for the continuation or appropriate projection of existing principal streets in surrounding areas or conform to a plan for the neighborhood approved by the planning and zoning commission and adopted by the city council to meet a particular situation where such continuation would be inappropriate c minor streets shall be oriented to discourage d where a subdivision abuts on or contains an existing or proposed arterial street the developer shall provide marginal access streets reserve frontage with screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation along the rear property line deep lots with rear service alleys or such other treatment as may be necessary for the adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation of local traffic e where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad rightofway or limited access highway rightofway the developer shall provide an access street approximately parallel to and on each side of such rightofway at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land as for park purposes in residential districts or for commercial or industrial purposes in appropriate districts distances involving rightsofway shall also be determined with due regard to the requirements of approach grades and future grade separation f reserve strips controlling access to streets shall be prohibited except where their control is definitely placed in the city under conditions prescribed by the planning and zoning commission and approved by the city council g street jogs with centerline offsets of less than two hundred 200 feet shall be avoided except where topographic situations make this provision impractical h a tangent at least two hundred and fifty 250 feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on arterial and collector streets i when connecting street lines deflect from each other at any one point by more than ten degrees 10 they shall be connected by a curve with a radius adequate to insure the sight distance of not less than one hundred and fifty 150 feet from minor streets three hundred 300 feet for collector streets and five hundred 500 feet for arterial streets j streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles and no streets shall intersect any other street at less than a sixty degree 60 angle k property lines at street intersections shall be rounded with a radius of ten 10 feet or of a greater radius where the planning and zoning commission may deem it necessary the planning and zoning commission may permit comparable cutoffs or chords in place of rounded corners l there shall be no private streets or easements for street use platted in any subdivision unless so recommended by the planning and zoning commission and approved by the city council m private streets as a principal means of access to individually owned lots shall be prohibited n minimum street rightofway widths unless otherwise indicated or required by law shall be as follows minimum rightofway width paving width residential district outside to outside paving width com ind dist outside to outside 1 street type major arterial 106 feet 32 feet 44 feet collector 70 feet 32 feet 44 feet minor 60 feet 27 feet 44 feet marginal access 40 feet 20 feet 32 feet 2 the planning and zoning commission shall determine a final designation of a street type from subparagraph 1 above rightsofway for marginal access streets may be reduced when conditions warrant b additional rightofway when required to promote public safety and convenience or to insure adequate access circulation and parking in high density residential commercial or industrial areas 3 curb radii at street intersections shall be a minimum of twentyfive 25 feet 4 where a subdivision abuts on or contains an existing street of inadequate rightofway width additional rightofway in conformity with the above standards shall be required for new subdivisions o the minimum centerline radii for horizontal curves shall be established as follows 1 the minimum radius for designated state roads or arterial streets shall be five hundred 500 feet except where a radius has otherwise been established by the department of transportation or the director of public works  2 the minimum radius for collector streets shall be one hundred 100 feet  and 3 the minimum radius for all other streets shall be sixty 60 feet p half or partial streets shall be prohibited q deadend streets designed to be so permanently shall be prohibited except where designed as a culdesac such streets shall not exceed eight hundred 800 feet in length without special permission of the planning and zoning commission where due to unusual circumstances a greater length may be deemed necessary they shall be provided at the closed end with a circular dedicated area with a diameter of not less than one hundred 100 feet with eighty 80 feet width of paving streets terminated temporarily shall end in a culdesac r street names and lot numbers shall conform to the street naming and lot numbering plan of the city s street grades shall be determined in relation to the drainage installations for the subdivision  wherever feasible street grades shall not exceed five per cent 5% or be less than twentyfive per cent 25% unless otherwise approved by the director of public works t proper sight lines must be maintained at all street intersections measured along the centerlines there must be a clear sight triangle of seventyfive 75 feet one hundred and fifty 150 feet for arterial streets from the point of intersection  no building or obstruction is permitted in this area u no wall fence or entrance gate shall be erected upon any dedicated public rightofway unless bonded perpetual care is otherwise provided by the developer and the design is approved by the planning and zoning commission  alleys a alleys shall be provided in commercial and industrial districts except that the planning and zoning commission may waive this requirement where other definite and assured provision is made for service access such as offstreet loading unloading and parking consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed b the width of an alley shall not be less than thirty 30 feet with a paving width of twentyfour 24 feet c alley intersections and sharp changes in alignment shall be avoided but where necessary corners shall be cut off sufficiently to permit safe vehicular movement d deadend alleys shall be prohibited  easements a easements across lots where necessary or centered on rear or side lot lines shall be provided for utilities and shall be at least seven and onehalf 712 feet wide except that easements where required for installation of sanitary and storm drainage systems and to meet other special utilities requirements shall be twelve 12 feet wide or as otherwise specified by the director of public works b where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse canal drainageway channel or stream there shall be provided a storm water easement or drainage rightofway conforming substantially with the lines of such watercourse and such further width or construction or both as will be adequate for the purpose the location and width of drainage easements shall be in conformity with the master drainage plan for the city parallel streets or parkways may be required in connection therewith where necessary for service maintenance and other measures for safety as may be required this maintenance strip shall be a minimum of twentyfive 25 feet in width c other easements may be required for drainage purposes of such size and location as may be determined by the director of public works d where necessary for safety and convenience pedestrian and service easements shall be provided such pedestrian and service easements may include or be included in easements required in a b and c above e required easements within proposed subdivisions shall be provided at no expense to the city  blocks a the lengths widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due regard to providing adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the type of use contemplated the zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions the needs for convenient access circulation control and safety of street and pedestrian traffic and fire protection and the limitations and opportunities of topography with special emphasis on drainage of the proposed subdivision and the possible adverse effects of that drainage on properties surrounding the subdivisions b block lengths shall not exceed one thousand five hundred 1500 feet or be less than eight hundred 800 feet in residential areas except that the planning and zoning commission may where special conditions exist recommend blocks of greater or lesser length c pedestrian crosswalks not less than ten 10 feet wide shall be required where deemed essential to provide circulation or access to schools playgrounds shopping centers transportation and other community facilities  a the lot size width depth shape and orientation and the minimum building setback lines shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated lot arrangement and design shall be such that all lots will provide satisfactory and desirable building sites b lot dimensions shall conform to the requirements of the city zoning code and 1 residential lots where not served by central water and sewer shall not be less than one and onehalf 112 times in width nor less than one and onehalf 112 times in area than the minimum zoning requirements for the zoning district in which the land is located  2 depth and width of properties reserved or laid out for commercial and industrial purposes shall be adequate to provide for the offstreet service and parking facilities required by the type of use and development contemplated c corner lots for residential use shall have extra width greater than a corresponding interior lot to permit appropriate building setbacks from any orientation to all streets d the subdividing of the land shall be such as to provide by means of a public street each lot with satisfactory and permanent access to an existing public street provided the planning and zoning commission may recommend private streets when constructed to the specifications of these regulations e double frontage and reverse frontage lots should be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation a planting screen easement of at least ten 10 feet and across which there shall be no right of access shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such a traffic artery f side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to street lines and entrance of automobiles from the lot to the street shall be approximately at right angles or radial to street lines g lakefront lots shall have minimum setback lines of fifty 50 feet from the established highwater mark and will conform to the provisions of the zoning code h no undeeded areas shall exist within a subdivision  parks and recreation sites a purpose in accordance with the authority granted by of the florida statutes and the parks and recreation element of the maitland comprehensive development plan all developers proposing land for residential subdivision are required to dedicate land or pay a fee in lieu of land for park andor recreational purposes it is hereby found and determined that the public interest convenience health welfare and safety require that a minimum of five 5 acres of property for each one thousand 1000 persons residing within the city be devoted to city park andor recreational purposes b requirements 1 where land is specified in the citys plan in those cases where the comprehensive development plan has designated any portion of the land within the proposed subdivision to be located in whole or in part therein as a park or recreational facility and provided the land to be dedicated is one acre or more then land shall be required from the developer in accordance with the land formula hereinafter stated and in accordance with the location as shown within the comprehensive development plan if the land area to be conveyed is less than one acre the city council shall have the option of requiring land or a fee in lieu of land from the developer 2 where land is not specified in the citys plan in those cases where the proposed subdivision does not lie within an area designated within the comprehensive development plan for parks or recreational facilities the city council shall have the option of requiring land or a fee in lieu of land from the developer this option shall be exercised upon determinations based on the following considerations a topography geology access and location of land in the subdivision available for parks andor recreational purposes  b size and shape of the proposed subdivision  c proximity and availability of land suitable for parks andor recreational purposes for the needs of the residents of the proposed subdivision  and d guidelines criteria andor other provisions of the parks and recreation element of the comprehensive development plan c standards 1 land formula the amount of land to be dedicated shall be determined pursuant to the following formula singlefamily subdivisions  2 acres100 dus twofamily or multifamily subdivisions  2 acres75 dus 2 fees in lieu of land the amount of fee shall be based on the fair market value of the developed land which would otherwise have been required according to the land formula developed land is defined as land within an approved subdivision in which all required improvements have been constructed and accepted by the city the amount of such fee shall be based upon an average estimated fair market value per subdivided developed acre located within the city d use of funds collected  manner of land conveyance 1 all money collected hereunder shall be used only for the purpose of providing park andor recreational facilities reasonably related to serving the residential development by way of purchase of necessary land or for improving of such land already acquired for these purposes if the city council deems there are sufficient recreational or park areas available for the development then the money may be used for improving other land for park andor recreational purposes within the city 2 all land conveyed to the city shall be in fee simple title e procedure at the time of approval of the preliminary plat the city council shall determine pursuant to this section the land to be dedicated andor the fees to be paid by the developer the determination of the city council shall be final and conclusive at the time of approval of the final plat and prior to signing of the record plat the developer shall convey such land or pay such fee in lieu thereof as was determined by the city council at the time of approval of the final plat the city council shall also specify the nature of the park andor recreational facilities to be developed pursuant to this section  secs 16461655  reserved article iv  required improvements footnotes  3  cross reference required improvements  7593xii generally approval of the final plat shall be subject to the subdivider having submitted to the city plans and specifications for all improvements required by the city these plans and specifications being approved by the appropriate city officials prior to commencement of construction and receipt of an acceptable performance bond a professional engineer registered by the state of florida shall be employed to design the required improvements after required improvements have been constructed such engineer shall submit certification to the city that the improvements have been constructed according to the approved plans and specifications  certification of completion upon completion of all work under bond the developer shall submit to the city manager a statement certified and sealed by a professional engineer registered in the state of florida stating that the work has been entirely completed that it was constructed under his supervision and that it conforms in all respects to the final plat and plans for required improvements and to the specifications set by these regulations  inspection report and acceptance upon receipt of this certificate of completion the director of public works shall make a final inspection of each of the contract operations on the site if the work conforms to all plans and specifications the city manager shall so inform the city council in writing and recommend acceptance by the city council action accepting the improvements shall constitute authority for release of the developers performance bond in the event the developer has not completed the construction of all improvements within the authorized time limitations the director of finance of the city shall when so directed by the city manager notify the surety company or such other organization furnishing the bond or its equivalent of pending default  maintenance bond required prior to release of the performance bond the developer shall provide a surety bond issued by a bonding company from the us treasury list of approved bonding companies or such other guarantee acceptable to the city in an amount equal to ten per cent 10% of the sum of the engineering and construction costs said bond referred to as the maintenance bond shall guarantee that all required improvements dedicated to the city have been properly constructed and are guaranteed for a period of one year  monuments a within each block of a subdivision at least two 2 monuments designed and designated as control corners shall be installed all monuments shall be constructed of concrete and shall be at least four 4 inches in diameter or square and not less than three 3 feet in length each monument shall have embedded in its top or attached by a suitable means a metal plate of noncorrosive material marked plainly with a point the surveyors registration number the month and year it was installed and the words permanent reference monument or the initials prm monuments shall be set in the ground so that the top is flush or no more than one foot below the finished grade b steel or wroughtiron pipe or the equivalent not less than threefourths 34 inch in diameter and at least thirty 30 inches in length shall be set at all block corners points of intersection points of curvature and points of tangency along the rightofway except those located by concrete monuments at the time of the final inspection of the required improvements a surveyors certificate indicating that the permanent reference monuments are in place shall be provided street signs or markers the developer will furnish and install street signs or markers at all intersections such markers or signs to be of a size and type specified by the city such street signs or markers shall be in place and approved as satisfactory by the director of public works prior to approval of the final plat street names shall be approved by the director of public works  sidewalks sidewalks shall be constructed on both sides of all streets of a subdivision except as provided elsewhere in this shall be located within the street rightofway and constructed in accordance with the requirements promulgated in standard specifications for road and bridge construction florida state department of transportation sidewalks shall be four 4 feet wide and four 4 inches deep unless structural insufficiency should necessitate engineering design resulting in a deviation from this depth however where sidewalks cross driveways the sidewalks will be six 6 inches in depth and reinforced with #10 steel wire mesh sidewalks will be emplaced at such time as the most proximate structure which the sidewalk serves is completed failure to conform to this requirement shall necessitate issuance of a stop work order by the building official on all structures under construction andor to be constructed in the subdivision by the particular builder in addition no final inspection will be made and surety bonds issued in favor of the city will not be released until all required sidewalks are in place  street lights a in order to provide for traffic safety to curb crime and vagrancy and to promote civic progress street lighting in subdivisions is required the system shall incorporate underground wiring and shall have a light intensity based on an expected pedestrian and traffic density as determined by the director of public works from the following table horizontal footcandles lumenssquare foot on the roadway pavement vehicular traffic classification vehicleshour pedestrian traffic less than less than less than more than heavy 150 400 1200 1200 medium 09 12 15 18 06 09 12 15 light or none 03 06 09 12 the lowest footcandle value at any point on the pavement should not be less than onesixth  16  the average b the selection of luminaries filament mercury or fluorescent lamps and poles to provide the required illumination should be compatible with the structure types in the subdivision the selection of these elements must be approved by the director of public works c the vertical height of lamps above the roadway will be such as to minimize direct glare and to provide reasonably uniform light distribution on the road and sidewalk surface the height determination is dependent on the type of luminaire and its candlepower the lamp and the pole the height must be approved by the director of public works d each developer is required to coordinate his plan with the electric utility that will provide the electrical service  street trees for the safety convenience and attractiveness of the subdivision street trees shall be provided these trees shall be a minimum caliper of one and onehalf 112 inches planted between the sidewalk and line at least five 5 feet from the sidewalk or where a planting strip is six 6 or more feet wide between the curb and sidewalk and be spaced not less than fifty 50 feet nor more than seventy 70 feet apart the director of public works shall approve the tree planting plan including the variety of street trees used  cross reference landscaping generally ch 8  trees and shrubs generally ch 19 utilities in residential subdivisions utility service connections to individual properties for electricity telephone gas and television communication shall be placed underground wherever possible utility lines shall be located along the rear lot lines  storm drainage a a storm drainage system shall be designed and installed in accordance with the master drainage plan for the city the plans must show the ultimate disposition of all surface water from the subdivision the system must be designed by a registered professional engineer in the state of florida all drainage facilities shall have adequate capacities to carry the runoff resulting from the maximum intensity rains which may be expected over a ten 10 year period where there is a substantial diversion of water such diversion shall be accomplished culvert or culverts in order to prevent erosion or flooding b all drainage facilities shall be designed for a positive outfall to existing storm sewer systems in accordance with the master drainage plan of the city c if the added runoff from the developed area will in the judgment of the director of public works overtax or overload existing facilities then the developer shall include in his plans sufficient work to enlarge the present facilities to care for the added drainage imposed on the system d where land may be subject to periodic flooding by the overflow from lakes canals or streams a flood plain must be established and clearly designated on the final plat no filling or building shall be permitted within the flood plain e construction of drainage facilities must be completed and the construction approved by the director of public works f wherein storm sewer facilities become a part of any construction or development appropriate interceptors shall be provided at the point of egress of the storm sewers or at such other point or points as the city may require wherein the effluent is dispensed directly or indirectly into lakes rivers or streams the size type and location of such interceptors shall be as approved by the city and shall be such that the removal of any material in the effluent that is not a physical and chemical part of the compound water will be effectively accomplished within known technical limits prior to entry of the effluent into the lake river or stream  cross reference drainage plans to accompany building permit applications  518  flood hazard prevention generally  574 et seq clearing and grading of rightsofway the developer shall be required to clear all rightsofway to their full paving width and to make all grades including grades for streets alleys and drainage to grades approved for the final plat all debris shall be removed from rightsofway  bridges and culverts a bridges shall be designed by a registered professional engineer and shall be wide enough to provide for curbs the standard paving width and in addition a five 5 foot sidewalk on one side of the roadway approach guardrails or fences shall be provided as required by the director of public works b culverts shall be designed in accordance with the requirements of the master drainage plan for the city they shall be of sufficient size to provide adequate drainage openings and of sufficient length to extend beyond the shoulder lines of the road culverts shall meet the standards specified by the director of public works c underground drains shall include one or more of the following and conform to the citys standards reinforced concrete pipe which meets astm and department of transportation specifications minimum diameter twelve 12 inches  or reinforced concrete box culverts d locations of bridges and culverts with construction data and full specifications shall be shown in an exhibit and approval or acceptance of the final plat shall not be accomplished unless such exhibit is transmitted e bridges and culverts must be constructed and approved by the director of public works before the developer is released from bond  sewer and water a city water sanitary sewer and storm sewer shall be provided in each new subdivision unless the planning and zoning commission determines after public hearing that conditions are such that this requirement or a portion of it may be set aside city water shall be available for fire control prior to commencing building construction subdivisions located within one thousand 1000 feet of a city sanitary sewer andor water line shall be required to be connected to the lines whenever the commission permits private septic tanks private sewerage systems or private water systems the plans must be approved by all requisite state county and city authorities before approval of the final plat b water and sewerage systems shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the standards and regulations of the state department of environmental protection county health department and the standards established herein these systems shall be designed by a florida registered professional engineer  construction shall be inspected and certified by a florida registered professional engineer  and three sets of asbuilt plans shall be prepared and furnished to the city upon completion of these systems c a looped central water system of six 6 inch water mains or larger connected to the citys system shall be provided in all residential or commercial subdivisions the system shall be designed and constructed to satisfy the domestic requirements established by the state department of environmental protection and the fire protection requirements established by the american insurance association as a minimum standard the distribution system shall be capable of delivering in addition to domestic requirements at residual pressures of not less than twenty 20 pounds per square inch fire flows of at least five hundred 500 gallons per minute in singlefamily residential subdivisions and one thousand two hundred fifty 1250 gallons per minute in commercial institutional and industrial areas fire hydrants of a type approved by the director of public works in singlefamily residential subdivisions shall be spaced no greater than five hundred 500 feet from any part of a building and shall be connected to mains the location installation and rental arrangements for fire hydrants shall be determined by the director of public works in collaboration with the chief of the fire department the design of the water system shall conform to the city of maitland master water plan all water mains shall be cast iron pipe all single service lines shall be a minimum of one 1 inch  all double service lines shall be a minimum of one and onehalf 112 inches d a central sanitary sewerage system shall be provided in all subdivisions unless requirement is waived by the planning and zoning commission and such waiver is approved by the city council the sewerage system must be designed in conformity with the city of maitland master sanitary sewerage plan this system shall have a minimum of eight 8 inch mains no sewerage system shall be designed or constructed in such a manner as to adversely affect the water quality of any existing stream lake or underground aquifer e whenever individual sewerage disposal systems are permitted the following conditions must be met 1 the soil and water table conditions on the lot must be satisfactory for the installation of drainfields pursuant to the regulations of the state department of environmental protection and the orange county health department  2 the use of individual sewerage systems would not hinder or obstruct the orderly and economic extension or development of the municipal system  and 3 such systems are located in the front yards or other locations which would provide a convenient and economical connection to a future sewerage system f cost of installing water sanitary sewer and storm sewer facilities shall be borne by the developer provided however that where the developer is required to install larger lines or facilities than necessary to serve his development in order to provide for future development the difference in costs between installing facilities adequate for the subdivision and the oversize lines shall be borne by the city  subdivisions shall make use of such oversize facilities and shall assess such cost to such future developers g facilities to be installed under this section must be constructed and approved by the director of public works before the developer is released from bond    32700 cross reference water and sewers generally ch 20 streets curbs and gutters a all streets and public ways shall be cleared and graded to their full paving width including side slopes and to the specified grade if required to prevent erosion or excessive washing of the shoulders protective measures shall be taken by the developer as required by the director of public works b a properly prepared subgrade and an approved road base and wearing surface shall be provided for all streets the subgrade must be of suitable material and must be prepared in accordance with standards established by the director of public works each street shall be paved to the minimum width established in section 1640n the following are minimum standards for roadway base materials collector minor and marginal access streets in industrial and commercial subdivisions and all arterial streets 1 8 of compacted limerock or 2 8 of compacted soil cement or 3 equivalent materials for which test data and design criteria have been approved by the director of public works collector minor and marginal access streets in residential subdivisions 1 6 of compacted limerock or 2 6 of compacted soil cement or 3 equivalent materials for which test data and design criteria have been approved by the director of public works the wearing surface shall consist of one of the following materials collector minor and marginal access streets in industrial and commercial subdivisions and all arterial streets 1 112 of type i asphaltic concrete surface course collector minor and marginal access streets in residential subdivisions 1 112 of type ii asphaltic concrete surface course or 2 equivalent materials for which test data and design criteria have been approved by the director of public works c concrete curbs and gutters shall be constructed on all streets and shall be installed according to the standards established by the director of public works  taxation footnotes  1  cross reference licenses and license taxes ch 9 state law reference the assessment and collection of authorized fs    levied a there is hereby imposed and levied by the city a tax upon the purchase of electricity metered or bottled liquefied petroleum or manufactured gas metered natural gas and fuel oil within the city in the amount of ten 10 percent of each payment received by the seller of such utility service or commodity  which tax shall be paid by the purchaser to the seller for the use of the city at the time of paying the charge therefor but not less often than monthly b there is hereby imposed and levied by the city a tax upon each and every purchase of telecommunications service which originates and terminates in this state at a rate of seven 7 percent of the total amount charged for any telecommunications service provided within the city or if the location of the telecommunications service provided cannot be determined the total amount billed for such telecommunications service to a telephone or telephone number a telecommunications number or device or a customers billing address located within the city excluding public telephone charges collected on site charges for any foreign exchange service or any private line service except when such services are used or sold as a substitute for any telephone company switched service or dedicated facility by which a telephone company provides a communication path access charges and any customer access line charges to a local telephone company however telecommunications service shall be taxed only on the monthly recurring customer service charges excluding variable usage charges c as used in this article terms shall have the meaning and definition given to them under fs   including the terms access charge or right of access local telephone service private communication service telecommunication service teletypewriter service and toll telephone service    42792   32700 exclusion of fuel adjustment charge the tax imposed by section 1711 hereof shall not be applied against any fuel adjustment charge and such charge shall be separately stated on each bill fuel adjustment charge shall mean all increases in the cost of utility services to the ultimate consumer resulting from an increase in the cost of fuel to the utility subsequent to  partial exemption for residential use the tax on electricity pursuant to section 1711 shall not be levied and collected on the first fifty 50 kilowatt hours per month purchased for residential use such exemption shall apply to each separate residential unit regardless of whether such unit is on a separate or central meter and shall be passed on to each individual tenant limit on tax on fuel oil notwithstanding the provisions of section 1711 the tax hereby levied on purchases of fuel oil shall not exceed four cents $004 per gallon duty of seller to collect  payment to city monthly a it shall be the duty of every seller of electricity metered or bottled liquefied petroleum or manufactured gas metered natural gas and fuel oil within the city to collect from the purchaser for the use of the city the tax levied under the provisions of section 1711 at the time of collecting the selling price thereof and to report and pay over on or before the 15th day of each calendar month to the city all such taxes levied and collected during the preceding calendar month it shall be the duty of every seller of telecommunication service within the city to collect from the purchaser for the use of the city the tax levied under the provisions of fs   et seq at the time of collecting the selling price thereof and to report and pay over to the city all such taxes levied and collected during the preceding calendar month and to file with the city a return as required by fs  9f on or before the 20th day of the succeeding month after the taxes are collected it shall be unlawful for any seller to collect for any such service without at the same time collecting the tax hereby levied unless such seller shall elect to assume and pay such tax without collecting the same from the purchaser any seller failing to collect such tax at the time of collecting for any such service shall be liable to the city for the amount of such tax  provided however the seller shall not be liable for the payment of such tax upon uncollected bills if any purchaser shall fail neglect or refuse to pay for any such service including the tax hereby imposed the seller shall have the right and is hereby authorized and empowered to immediately discontinue further service to such purchaser until the same is paid in full b for the purpose of compensating the seller of telecommunication service the seller shall be allowed one 1 percent of the amount of the tax collected and due to the city in the form of a deduction from the amount collected for remittance the deduction shall be allowed as compensation for the keeping of records and for the collection of and the remitting of the tax the deduction shall not be allowed in the event of an untimely return unless the seller has in writing requested and been granted an extension of time for filing such return c notwithstanding any other provisions of this section in the event the total amount of tax anticipated to be collected within a calendar quarter does not exceed one hundred twenty dollars $12000 the seller of telecommunication service may with written authorization of the city remit the taxes collected during such quarter to the city quarterly in such case the tax shall be due on or before the 20th day of the month following the end of the calendar quarter in which the taxes were collected    42792   32700 record of sales  inspection by city each and every seller of electricity metered or bottled liquefied petroleum or manufactured gas metered natural gas and fuel oil shall keep complete records showing all sales in the city of such commodities or services which records shall show the price charged upon each sale the date thereof and the date of payment and such records shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized agents of the city during business hours on all business days  and such duly authorized agents of the city shall have the right power and authority to make any transcripts thereof during such times as they may desire    42792   32700 public agencies and certain other organizations exempt from tax all federal state and municipal purposes enumerated herein shall make application in writing to the city manager requesting the exemption herein provided this tax exemption herein provided shall become effective with the next designated as a brownfield area pursuant to fs  37680 business  an activity engaged in by any person or entity with the object of private or public gain benefit or advantage either direct or indirect
