guineas or other similar fowl preliminary development plan the proposal for development of a planned development preliminary subdivision plan those submittals required by and following the procedures of the city subdivision regulations professional office the office of a member of a recognized profession maintained for the conduct of that profession property owner the legal or beneficial owner or owners of all land within the boundaries of a legally described lots or parcels quality neighborhood program qnp qnp is a process by which residential neighborhoods identify and implement improvement strategies to upgrade substandard neighborhood conditions and to ensure neighborhood quality and maintenance of the neighborhoods this is accomplished formal review process which consists of 1 the demonstration of a neighborhoods desire to engage in a selfimprovement program  2 neighborhood participation in the planning process  3 substantiation of substandard conditions within the neighborhood based upon an assessment of elements contained within a monitoring list used to determine the overall neighborhood stability and provide a wellrounded impression of the neighborhood conditions these include elements such as the existence of central sewer potable water and plumbing pavement conditions including bike paths and sidewalks drainage tree canopy traffic circulation vacancy rates this assessment is accomplished by the city  4 preparation of a neighborhood plan with the assistance of the city staff  and 5 a sharing of costs of the improvement between the city and the citizens radio station the commercial or noncommercial dissemination of radio communications intended to be received by the public and operated between the frequencies of 535 and 1605 kilohertz inclusive or between eightyeight 88 and one hundred eight 108 megahertz inclusive as regulated by the federal communications commission providing programming with or without colocated main or auxiliary transmitter facilities residential rehabilitation center a community residential facility operated primarily for the diagnosis treatment or rehabilitation of clients which facility provides in a structured residential setting individualized continuing evaluation planning twentyfourhour supervision and coordination and integration of health or rehabilitative services to help each client reach his maximum functioning capabilities the capacity shall not be less than seventeen 17 clients residential scale and character a design principle applied to nonresidential uses or mixed uses based upon the criteria found in section 2124 that relies upon the incorporation of specific design elements that cause structures and other site improvements to substantially resemble or give the perception of residential structures in the context of size and shape of the buildings  pitch of the roofs  type of building materials used  building fenestrations and detailing landscaping site organization and reduced parking mass residential scale retail uses and services shall relate to the design elements of residential scale and character listed in section 2124 and shall reflect the neighborhood scale and be so located to be reasonably accessible for pedestrians and alternative modes of transportation restaurant an establishment where food and drink is prepared served and consumed primarily within the principal building rightofway  the strip of land owned or controlled by the city or another governmental agency over which the public has a right of passage including the streets parkways medians sidewalks and driveways constructed thereon for the purpose of this document rightofway excludes alleys satellite dish a device a which includes an antenna or dish antenna the purpose of which is to transmit or receive communication or other signals from orbiting satellites and other extraterrestrial sources b which includes a lownoise amplifier lna which is situated at the focal point of the receiving component the purpose of which is to magnify and transfer signals  and c which usually includes a coaxial cable whose purpose is to carry signals into the interior of any building or other structure setback the distance between the center line of a street and the front side or rear line of a building excluding projections specifically permitted or in the case of districts requiring yards all required yard shall be measured from such setback lines shall may the word shall is mandatory  the word may is permissive shopping center a group of commercial establishments planned constructed and managed as a total entity with customer and employee parking provided onsite provision for goods delivery separated from customer access aesthetic considerations and protection from the elements sidewalk  an improved walkway intended primarily for pedestrians usually running parallel to one 1 or both sides of the pavement of a street site plan an illustration of the details of development of areas such as but not limited to commercial industrial recreational and multiplefamily residential uses the required submittals and processing procedures shall be as specified in the site plan review process square an area that includes paved walks lawns trees and ornamental structures such as fountains and gazebos a square is located at the intersection of two 2 streets storefront the side of a store that faces the street or parking lot and includes the main entrance and display windows storefronts downtown maitland  the type of facade a commercial style building would have at the street level storefronts emphasize transparency and normally include large display windows with framing  a recessed entrance  a cornice or a horizontal sign panel at the top of the storefront to separate it from the upper facade  and low bulkheads at the base to protect the windows and define the entrance story that portion of a building included between the surface of any finished floor and the surface of the next finished floor above it or if there is no floor above it then the space between such floor and ceiling next above it unless such space is less than five and onehalf 55 feet in height wherever the height between two 2 finished floors or finished floor and ceiling exceeds twentyfive 25 feet each height of fifteen 15 feet or portion greater than five and onehalf 55 feet thereof shall be construed to be one 1 story story downtown maitland  the space in a building between two 2 adjacent floor levels or between a floor and a roof basements that emerge less than four 4 feet from grade or attics with or without dormer windows not exceeding five and onehalf 55 feet shall not constitute a story whenever a story exceeds twentyfive 25 feet in height measured from the finished floor to the bottom of the slab above each height of fifteen 15 feet or portion thereof shall be construed to be one 1 story street a public or approved private thoroughfare which affords the principal means of access to abutting property street wall  a low solid or semisolid wall that provides a defined urban edge along an alley or street structure anything constructed erected or placed including all temporary fixed or movable construction and which shall include buildings signs mobile homes walls fences tents lunch wagons or other structures on wheels or other supports and used for business commercial office or living purposes utility poles are exempt tense the present tense includes the future tense travel lanes the number of to be provided in each direction not applicable for yield movement faculties tod study area a as designated on the future land use map 1bd within the citys comprehensive development plan which is designed to provide support to urban infill development redevelopment and the achievement of the citys redevelopment goals by addressing mobility urban design land use mix and network connectivity transit oriented development tod overlay district a district established by the city of maitland comprehensive development plan 2030 to guide the future development and redevelopment surrounding the maitland commuter rail station to create opportunities for compact pedestrian and bicycle friendly neighborhood centers accessible to transit the tod overlay district shall be comprised of two 2 study areasstudy area a and study area b study area a and b shall be mapped within the city of maitland comprehensive development plan future land use map series study area a represents the area of the tod district that shall be evaluated for future economic development opportunities as well as evaluation and determination of areas that may be appropriate for future increased residential densities and increased nonresidential intensities use any purpose for which a building or other structure or a tract of land may be designed arranged intended maintained or occupied  or any activity occupation business or operation conducted on or intended to be conducted on any building or other structure or on a tract of land use of land includes use of land water surface and land under water to the extent covered by zoning districts and over which it is occupied or maintained use principal the primary or predominant use for which land or structure may be used as permitted by the applicable zoning district used occupied the word used or occupied includes the words intended designed or arranged to be used or occupied variance a variance is a relaxation of the terms of this zoning code where such variance will not be contrary to the public interest and where owing to conditions peculiar to the property and not the result of the actions of the applicant a literal enforcement of this zoning code would result in unnecessary and undue hardship on the land as used in this zoning code a variance is authorized only for height area and size of structure or size of yards and open spaces establishment or expansion of a use otherwise prohibited shall not be allowed by variance nor shall a variance be granted because of the presence of nonconformities in the zoning division or district or adjoining zoning divisions of districts yard a required open space other than a court unoccupied and unobstructed by any structure or portion of a structure from thirty 30 inches above the general ground level of the graded lot upward provided however that fences walls poles posts childrens play equipment and other customary yard accessories ornaments and furniture may be permitted in any yard subject to height limitations and requirements limiting obstruction of visibility diagrams on how to measure various types of yards are found at the end of the definitions of various types of yards yard front a space extending the full width of the lot between side lot lines across the front of a lot adjoining a street such front yard is unoccupied and unobstructed from the ground upward except as may be permitted elsewhere in the ordinance in the case of unless the prevailing front yard pattern on adjoining lots indicates otherwise front yards shall be provided on all frontages where one 1 of the front yards that would normally be required on a is not in keeping with the prevailing yard pattern the zoning administrator may waive the requirements for the normal front yard and substitute therefor a special yard requirement which shall not exceed the average of the yards provided on adjacent lots in the case of corner lots front yards of the required depth shall be provided on both frontages depth of required front yards shall be measured at right angles to a straight line joining the foremost points of the side lot lines the foremost point of the side lot line in the case of rounded property corners at street intersections shall be assumed to be the point at which the side and front lot lines would have met without such rounding front and rear front yard lines shall be parallel yard side a yard extending from the rear line of the required front yard to the rear lot line or in the absence of any clearly defined rear lot line to the point on the lot farthest from the intersection of the lot line involved with the public street in the case of side yards shall extend from the rear lines of front yards required in the case of corner lots yards remaining after full depth front yards have been established on both frontages shall be considered side yards width of a required side yard shall be measured in such a manner that the yard established is a strip of the minimum width required by district regulations with its inner edge parallel with the side lot line yard rear a yard extending across the rear of the lot between inner yard lines in the case of corner lots there will be no rear yards depth of a required rear yard shall be measured in such a manner that the yard established is a strip of the minimum width required by district regulations with its inner edge parallel with the rear lot line yard special a yard behind any required yard adjacent to a public street required to perform the same functions as a side or rear yard but adjacent to a lot line and so placed or oriented that neither the term side yard nor the term rear yard clearly applies in such cases the zoning administrator shall require a yard with minimum dimensions as generally required for a side yard or a rear yard in the district the appropriate yard shall be determined based up the relation of the portion of the lot on which the yard is to be located to the adjoining lot or lots with due regard to the orientation and location of structures and buildable areas thereon zoning code of the land development code sic the accompanying diagrams on the following pages indicate the location of yards on rectangular and nonrectangular lots  112690   71392   12593   112795   32700   91304   121106   11810  exh a 102411  exh a  4 51412   111014    82718  editors note of provides that the ordinances pertaining to satellite dishes shall be repealed on  residential scale and character i general in determining residential scale and character the city shall consider as a general guideline whether the buildings exhibit architectural elements and features characteristic of residential structures of similar scale and mass with consideration given to size and shape of the buildings  pitch of the roofs  type of building materials used  building fenestrations and detailing whether there is an abundance of landscaping and site organization and giving articulation to the appearance of a smaller and reduced parking mass ii criteria for review the following criteria shall serve as a framework to review development applications but shall not mandate that every element must be provided final determination as to whether a development is of residential scale and character shall be subject to the approval of the appropriate city of maitland board charged with reviewing the application for development a building shapes and form buildings with lengthy unbroken facades should be avoided as a general guide the maximum horizontal length of an unbroken facade plane should be fiftyfeet facade offsets should be incorporated to create shadow lines an essential character of residential scale is a traditional appearance of building walls and openings walls define the overall form of the building while openings give them human scale residential character building components include elements such as decks and balconies and roof configurations which reflect traditional residential features such as pitched hip or gable residential character can also include parapets and a combination of flat and pitched roofs height limitations or design preferences may dictate a flat roof b building fenestration and detailing may incorporate window features such as punched as opposed to banded or continuous windows  groupings of windows that are not generally found in larger office or residential buildings and which may be separately defined by mullions may include muntins multipane windows doublehung windows or casement windows  crown and other moldings  overhangs  soffits  building ornamentation  and architectural elements such as doorways archways arches and columns dormers and gables clearly defined entries facing the street should be provided features that visually reduce the height mass and scale of the structure such as clearly defining the base middle and cap of the building address residential scale and character c site organization may be used to establish residential character including clustering of buildings the manner in which buildings are organized on the site and building massing where special attention is made to its massing by the grouping of forms and spaces to reflect more of a human scale creating friendly pedestrian scaled exterior spaces by grouping of smaller structures as well as indenting or setting back some upper floors or portions of upper floors add an element of residential scale buildings should be located so that the front door faces the main street d building materials brick accents of brick stucco stone wood or natural materials are generally more reflective of residential character the scale of materials should be smaller and relate to a more finegrained character reflective of residential architecture ie using brick to create a smaller modular scale instead of large panels and using architectural detailing including trim framing fenestration and articulation is encouraged instead of creating continuous uniform surfaces onsite parking parking should be deemphasized as much as possible if possible parking should not be placed in the front of the building but if so located shall be screened by hedges and other landscape materials and may include the incorporation of a low screen wall approximately twentyfour 24 to thirty 30 inches in height parking lots should be screened or broken up by landscaping reduced parking mass in lieu of an expanse of parking should be provided surface stormwater facilities such as stormwater ponds and swales should be integrated into the parking lot design incorporating landscaping and other aesthetic treatments and used as amenities e landscape design and amenities the following landscape design and amenities principals shall be considered incorporation of unique and existing trees into the landscape design use of layering to promote informality with a variety of plants with differing mature heights use wide variety of plants in informal arrangements use of plants or trees which have seasonal color  accommodate the topography in site planning including planted slopes  incorporate other site amenities such as a gazebo trellis and yardsite furniture to help create the perception of a residential development exh a  15 102411 special districts maitland west side special district purpose and intent the function of the maitland west side special district is to establish specific design and performance standards consistent with the maitland west side redevelopment plan exh b 102411   district designation the maitland west side special district includes all real property shown within map 231 maitland westside special district map exh b 102411   alternative design standards exceptions process an applicant may request to use alternative design standards during the development review and approval process deviation from the network connectivity and design standards provided herein shall be specifically delineated by the applicant and submitted to the city staff as part of the applicable development application process for review and action upon approval by the city council any such alternative design standards shall be incorporated as a binding condition of the development application approval exh b 102411   design principles for maitland west side the following urban design principles that shall guide the future development and redevelopment of the maitland west side area are a development patternmix support a viable mixeduse area that is regionally and nationally competitive by providing flexibility necessary to meet future real estate market needs b adopt a livable diverse approach to transportation create a more connected accessible place with increased network alternate modes transit supportive uses and more walkable street designs c provide choices for the workforce serve the employment base with attainable housing and proximate transportation choices within the area d increase access to neighborhood commercial uses serve the employment base and nearby residents with convenient services packaged in walkable mixeduse nodes accessible to transit e feature the open space and public realm place usable and accessible open space and trails in a front door street relationship where feasible connected as an amenity for everyone in the area to include the parkway loop as described in the master plan f image appearance and development form enhance the image function and relevance of maitlands west side to the residents and workforce quality new development and increased expectations for design of livable mixeduse and interesting places exh b 102411   circulation this section includes several components of circulation including the addition of a street cross section for local streets that provide for onstreet parking  the identification of street types for the purposes of regulating site design  block standard preferences  access  and pedestrian connectivity exh b 102411 street design the following street sections may be utilized for any newly constructed streets within the maitland west side area standard streets and commercial streets i aisles shall be required when any new building except accessory buildings is erected on an existing developed parcel or undeveloped land the preferred block length shall range from four hundred 400 to seven hundred 700 feet including alleys or drive aisles that may bisect the block  however the maximum block perimeter should not exceed two thousand six hundred 2600 feet iii block configuration any additional development within the maitland west side area shall be required to create a block structure as provided herein a any new development including additional buildings that are constructed on an existing parcel with existing constructed buildings shall provide 1 a continuous drive aisle that meets the standards in the vehicular access section section 23 for connections to adjacent parcels  and 2 be consistent with the maximum block perimeter to the extent that is practical given the parcel size exh b 102411 vehicular access i joint use driveways and cross access easements a system of joint use driveways and cross access easements shall be established and shall incorporate the following a a unified access and circulation system plan that includes coordinated or shared parking areas is encouraged wherever feasible b a continuous service drive or cross access shall be provided stubouts and other design features shall be used to make it visually obvious where the cross accessservice drive connections exist c a circulation plan shall be submitted which identifies potential crossand jointaccess to adjacent parcels pedestrian accommodations and alternative transportation modes shall be reflected in the submitted circulation plan ii standards for drive aisles the following three 3 drive aisles shall be considered the connected drive aisles drive aisle configurations no parking parallel parking angled parking travel lanes each direction 1 1 1 aisle dimensions travel lanes width feet  each direction 10 10 12 parking lane widthdimensions na 20 885 public or private 44 6280 5664 in the interest of promoting unified access and circulation systems development sites under the same ownership or consolidated for the purposes of development and comprised of more than one 1 building site shall not be considered separate properties in relation to the access standards of this number of connections permitted shall be the minimum number necessary to provide reasonable access to these easements agreements and stipulations required under joint use driveways and cross access easements this shall also apply to phased development plans all access to outparcels must be internalized using the shared circulation system of the principal development access to outparcels shall be designed to avoid excessive movement across parking aisles and queuing across surrounding parking and driving aisles iii pedestrian connectivity the pedestrian network shall provide direct pedestrian and bicycle pathways to surrounding buildings adjacent parcels surrounding streets external sidewalks adjacent trails transit stops parking areas future phases of development and adjacent developments to the site pedestrian standards include two 2 components circulation and design a circulation one of the following types of pedestrian facilities shall be placed along each side of a block 1 continuous sidewalks five 5 feet to twenty 20 feet in width along roadways 2 alleys less than or equal to five hundred 500 feet in length  or 3 boardwalks  or 4 multiuse trails b the design of the pedestrian standards shall include 1 pedestrian pathways and sidewalks shall be well lit and physically separated from driveways and parking spaces by landscaping barriers grade separations or other means to protect pedestrians from vehicular traffic 2 a crosswalk shall be required when a sidewalk crosses a public driveway cross access or a paved area accessible to vehicles 3 crosswalks shall be designed and coordinated to move people safely to and from buildings and parking areas where pathways cross a parking area driveways or road they shall be clearly marked with contrasting paving material humps raised crossing or painted striping 4 whenever walkways are provided raised crosswalks or other trafficcalming measures shall be used to slow traffic 5 crosswalks shall be located at all points where a sidewalk crosses a lane of vehicular travel 6 the pedestrian network shall be in a connected block pattern throughout the developed area and shall occur at a minimum every 500 feet  7 for parcels greater than 4 acres the applicant shall evaluate the need for shelters benches chairs as a part of circulation plan exh b 102411   site design and lot layout lot layout the following standards shall be applied to any new developmentredevelopment in the west side area within the oc and oc3 zoning districts any new properties rezoned to planned development after october 201 and any existing approved planned developments that seek to increase the approved development program lot requirements min max lot coverage % 75 open space % 1 30 building envelope min max street setback feet 2  main street 15 50 primary street 25 50 secondary street 50  common lot setback feet  10  building height feet  heights shall be restricted to one hundred and fifty feet for properties within two hundred feet of keller road rightofway to interstate 4 all other properties may be permitted to a height of two hundred and five feet consistent with other applicable requirements per the city of maitlands comprehensive development plan 203 policy  parking provisions3 location main street siderear primary siderear 1 an applicant may be credited for existing open space areas on their site or development parcel when these areas meet the standards for open space as provided herein 2 the applicant may request modifications in the setback to preserve the existing tree canopy and easements 3 if site constraints exist the community development director may permit alternative areas for parking exh b 102411 building placement the following requirements are for nonresidential and attached residential buildings buildings shall orient the primary facade towards the street this includes the main entrances and windows to face the street a building frontages located on a main street or primary streets shall occupy no less than fifty 50 percent of a buildings street frontage entrance up to onethird  13  of the required percentage may consist of arcades or frontage walls the frontage wall shall be a minimum height of eighteen 18 inches with a maximum height of twentyfour 24 inches and a minimum width of eight 8twelve 12 inches the wall shall be constructed of stone brick wrought iron or stucco if the knee wall is constructed with wrought iron the minimum width standards shall not apply the material shall complement the primary buildings architecture exh b 102411 open space open space requirements may be met by existing landscape that meets the citys landscape standards pedestrian connections additional public space and enhanced storm water facilities as amenities see definition of open space wekiva area section 2123 public space any development greater than four 4 acres in size shall provide five 5 percent of the total building square footage area for public space the public space can be restricted to the building providing the public space and is not required to be open to the general public the public space requirements shall be met by providing any of the following a green a space available for unstructured recreation a green is landscaped with lawns and trees including existing or natural vegetation and paths and trails b square an area that includes paved walks lawns trees and ornamental structures such as fountains and gazebos c outdoor seating an area with tables and chairs potentially covered umbrella seating this area can also function as an outdoor cafe that is open to the public for eating andor drinking d courtyards an area that may have landscape hardscape andor fountains which provide a seated area e community garden garden plots an area available to residents for small scale cultivation f plaza a space at the intersection of streets devoted to civic purposes and temporary commercial activities such as craft shows farmers markets etc exh b 102411 stormwater additional design standards for stormwater facilities to be permitted to count toward the minimum open space requirements of these regulations stormwater facilities shall be required to meet the following minimum design standards a stormwater facilities ponds andor depressions shall be designed and utilized as site amenities along entrances and street frontages or incorporated with buffers between incompatible uses b stormwater facilities should be designed and permitted so as not to require fencing if fencing is required a green or black vinylpainted finish is required walls or other railings for structured stormwater boxes must be decorative max fence height four 4 feet  c subject to the requirements of st johns river management district other governmental agencies and a consideration of safety related issues stormwater facilities that are located in the front of a property shall be prohibited from having fencing unless it can be demonstrated to be necessary due to the configuration and topography of the lot the determination of necessity in this circumstance shall be made by the city council as a part of the evaluation of a design waiver to the maitland west side design standards d wet stormwater detentionretention facilities adjoining public streets shall include a water feature such as a fountain or spray jet and shall be planted with appropriate aquatic materials as specified in table 231 approved aquatic plant materials list detentionretention along the front of a property shall be designed with curvilinear edges  not as a straight box retention embankments shall be planted with one 1 tree per fifty 50 linear feet of retention perimeter measured from top of slope trees shall be suitable for wet locations as identified in table 231 approved aquatic plant materials list e dry retention areas shall be planted with grass and unless maintained as an open lawn swale shall be screened from view with a continuous hedge of shrubs on thirtysixinch centers around at least seventyfive 75 percent of the perimeter at the top of the slope f dry retention areas may also be constructed as a multiuse facility if utilizing low impact design standards the applicant must identify the methods being used to be considered acceptable for obtaining open space credit for the dry retention design table 231 approved aquatic plant materials list approved aquatic plant material list upper littoral zone 6inches above or below the normal water level taxodium disticum bald cypress large native tree iris hexagona blue flag iris native perennial scirpus califoricus giant bulrush canna flaccida golden canna native plant spartina bakeri cordgrass middle littoral zone from 1 inch to 3 inch below normal water level sagittatia lancifolia arrowhead native plant taxodium ascendens pond cypress large native tree pontederia cordata pickerel weed native perennial plant lower littoral zone from 3 inch to 5 inch below normal water level nymphaea odorata fragrant white water lily other aquatic plants may be used from the list of aquatic plants found in florida as prepared by the florida department of natural resources bureau of aquatic plant management exh b 102411 pedestrian connections if a property is eligible to develop a portion of a trail system bikeway system that are linked to additional parcels and development of the trail or bikeway may count towards the open space requirement the standards for this are located in the pedestrian connectivity section of section 231 exh b 102411   general building design standards the following standards apply to all buildings that are located within the maitland west side development area exh b 102411 screening requirements a loading docks truck parking outdoor storage hvac equipment trash dumpsters trash compactors and other service functions shall not be visible from any street or sidewalk or adjacent residential area these facilities may be incorporated into the overall design of the principal building using screening walls of compatible material style color texture pattern trim and details whether these service functions are attached or detached from the principal building b the screening wall shall be one foot higher than the largest object being screened but not more than eight feet high on all sides where access is not needed an opaque gate with the same height as the wall shall be included where access is needed c mechanical equipment at ground level shall be placed away from view from any streets sidewalks and residential areas the mechanical equipment shall be screened from view by fencing vegetation or parapet walls if located on a roof using the same materials as the principal building ie stone brick or stucco the screening shall be at least equal to the width and height of the equipment to be screened from view exh b 102411 building faade new buildings shall provide a foundation or base typically from ground to bottom of the lower windowsills with changes in volume or material a clear visual division shall be maintained between the ground level floor and upper floors with either a cornice line or awning from twelve 12 feet to sixteen 16 feet above base floor elevation or grade whichever applies to the proposed development exh b 102411 building features all new buildings shall utilize at least three of the following design features to provide visual relief along all elevations of the building a divisions or breaks in materials or textures materials should be drawn from a common palette b window bays c separate entrances and entry treatments porticoes extending at least five 5 feet d variation in roof lines e awnings installed in increments of fifteen 15 feet or less f dormers g canopies extending at least five 5 feet h overhang extending at least five 5 feet i recessed entries at least three 3 feet from the primary facade j protruding entries at least three 3 feet from the primary facade k covered porch entries exh b 102411 public entrance new buildings that are open to the public shall have an entrance for pedestrians from the street to the building interior this entrance shall be designed to be a distinctive and prominent element of the architectural design and shall be open to the public during business hours buildings shall incorporate lighting and changes in mass surface or finish which places an emphasis to the entrance exh b 102411 parking structure the following urban standards shall apply to parking structures a the entrances to structured parking should be from secondary streets only b direct pedestrian access from parking garages to any adjacent street shall be provided c the exterior facades of all parking garages fronting on any street shall be designed to achieve an architectural unity with the block d parking garages shall comply with all building design standards for building facade scale building features and lighting compatibility and placement on the site e the city may approve other design alternatives such as liner buildings around the outer edge of the garage exh b 102411 additional main street standards the main street designated area in maitland west side as defined in section 23 network pattern should provide the following design elements storefront character and building orientation i storefront character new buildings shall be designed to create a storefront character storefront character shall be met by providing all of the following architectural features along the street building frontage as applicable a corner building entrances on corner lots b regularly spaced and similarshaped windows with window hoods or trim all building stories c large display windows on the ground floor facades of all buildings facing streets parks and plazas shall have windows covering a minimum of forty 40 percent and a maximum eighty 80 percent of the surface area of the ground floor of each storefronts linear frontage blank walls shall not occupy over fifty 50 percent of a streetfacing frontage and shall not exceed thirty 30 feet  without being interrupted by a window or entry mirrored glass obscured glass and glass block cannot be used in meeting this requirement d the bottom edge of display windows on the ground floor facades shall be no more than thirty 30 inches above finished floor level ii building orientation the primary building entrances shall be visible and directly accessible from a street building massing such as tower elements shall be used to callout the location of building entries iii mass and scale new building shall be constructed such that no more than sixty 60 feet  of horizontal distance of wall shall be constructed without architectural relief a minimum of thirty 30 feet  wide and three 3 feet  deep for building walls and frontage walls facing the street for nonresidential and attached residential buildings exh b 102411 downtown maitland special district purpose and intent the function of the downtown maitland special district is to guide future development and redevelopment toward creating an attractive urban pattern that balances the pedestrian and traffic needs of residents and to encourage but not require mixeduse development by generally desiring residential use development to be provided above commercial andor office use while it protects and enhances the original pattern of development consistent with the goals of the citys comprehensive plan downtown master plan and the downtown maitland revitalization plan downtown maitland extends generally from maitland boulevard on the north to the csx railroad overpass on the south and includes three subdistricts referred to as the sawmill packwood and waterhouse districts the packwood district is the focal point of the downtown maitland revitalization area and includes the citys town center and core area the intent of the packwood district is to encourage economic viability by creating a mixture of public and private uses to promote walkability and activation of the retail core of the citys downtown the packwood district represents the heart of the city and is intended for a vigorous mixture of commercial and residential uses that create a magnetic gathering place for citizens it will contain a concentration of commercial civic and cultural uses interspersed with mixed use developments and urban open spaces buildings will be positioned close to the street to encourage pedestrian activity and to create a main street urban pattern design components central to the intent include clustering of buildings buildings with distinctive storefronts balconies and inviting entrances as well as outdoor seating and cafes that interact with the street buildings will have diverse architectural types which incorporate decorative elements and attractive roof elements the sawmill and waterhouse districts serve as the northern and southern entries to downtown maitland and are intended to achieve the vision of a pedestrianoriented mixeduse area the sawmill district represents the north gateway to the city and includes maitlands sunrail station the focus of this district is to create a transit supportive place the area will be based upon transit oriented principles such as a pedestrian and bicycle friendly environment with a compact and functional mix of uses design components central to the intent include a mix of residential employment and supporting retail and service uses high densitiesintensities around the transit station and compact development form grouping of buildings to allow for easy pedestrian access between buildings building architecture will include faade treatments that reduce building scale to include gables covered walks awnings storefront windows and building interaction with the sidewalk system the waterhouse district represents the southern gateway to the city the focus of the district is a safe compact pedestrianfriendly mixed use business district that serves neighborhoods within walking distance design components central to the intent include buildings with distinctive store fronts balconies and entrances that connect with the street buildings with decorative elements and roofs which encourage a variety of street views and diverse architectural styles additional criteria have been established for groundfloor residential development within the packwood sawmill and waterhouse districts to promote economic viability and to achieve a mixture of uses for downtown maitland refer to section 2121 planned development and  the location of groundfloor residential within each district will be evaluated based upon compatibility with surrounding uses the character of the surrounding areas street types road visibility street frontage access and the purpose and intent of each district the design and land development standards are intended to be flexible and encourage design diversity and variation the criteria for development in the district will ensure that the architectural integrity and details of existing significant structures are maintained and will affirm the appropriateness of new development into the historic fabric of the area exh b 102411  exh a  5 51412   41116    district designation a purpose  the downtown maitland special district serves as an overlay district and includes all real property shown within downtown maitland future land use designation as adopted in the city comprehensive development plan cdp b applicability  where any provision of section 232 is in conflict with any standards or regulations within the downtown maitland master plan adopted by in october 199 as may be amended from time to time the standards contained herein shall prevail all new development within the downtown maitland special district shall comply with the standards contained in sections 216 and 2323 the entire development shall be brought into compliance with the standards if 1 the total building floor area on a building site is being increased by more than thirty 30 percent  or 2 more than fifty 50 percent of the total building floor area on a building site is being replaced  or 3 there is a combination of building floor area increase and building floor area replacement exceeding fifty 50 percent of the original building floor area on a development site  or 4 existing buildings are being redeveloped and the cost of redevelopment is greater than fifty 50 percent of the assessed value of all the buildings on the development site prior to the improvements c architecture review  the citys development review committee drc may obtain assistance from a design professional when reviewing development proposals for compliance with the architectural standards contained in this section exh a  6 51412   flexibility in design standards application design waivers it is recognized that because of the individual unique characteristics or circumstances of any given development flexibility in the application of development requirements may be warranted in certain situations waivers from the standards provided in sections 216 and 232 including all subsections within andor the standards contained in the downtown maitland development standards manual shall be specifically requested and delineated by the applicant and submitted to the city staff as part of the preapplication process if an applicant requests multiple waivers each waiver shall be evaluated independently land use waivers are not permitted under this section and waivers are not applicable to properties zoned planned development a waivers may be reviewed andor approved by drc the planning and zoning commission and city council as set forth below 1 drc shall review and approve requests for waivers up to ten 10 percent of any dimensional requirement 2 waivers of ten 10 percent or more of a dimensional requirement and waivers of nondimensional requirements shall be reviewed and approved by the planning and zoning commission in accordance with the procedures established in section 7583iii 3 waivers involving activities such as financial contributions land swaps financial obligations or continuing maintenance by the city shall be reviewed by the city council in accordance with the procedures established in subsection 7583ivc refer to subsection 7583ivc for additional examples b a waiver may be granted by the approving authority if it finds that strict application of requirements of section 216 section 232 or the standards manual is not warranted and that granting a waiver will fulfill the intent of this ldc the approving authority shall apply all the following criteria when applicable to determine if the applicant has justified a request for a waiver to a dimensional requirement and if granting the proposed waiver will fulfill the intent of this ldc 1 the request is consistent with the cdp and generally consistent with the purpose of the ldc and the downtown maitland master plan 2 the proposed waiver will not have a material negative impact on adjacent uses or the applicant proposes to mitigate the negative impact to be created by the waiver 3 compliance with the requirement is technically impractical or undesirable based on site conditions or approval of the waiver will result in superior design 4 the request would not have a material negative effect the public health safety and welfare 5 the applicant may provide other information in addition to that listed above to justify a request for a waiver and demonstrate that granting the proposed waiver will fulfill the intent of this ldc and the comprehensive development plan c the burden of presenting evidence sufficient to satisfy the applicable criteria set forth in this section as well as the burden of persuasion on those issues remains with the applicant seeking the waiver d in granting a waiver the approving authority may impose such reasonable conditions as will ensure that the use of the property to which the waiver applies will be reasonably compatible with the surrounding properties including visual screening e as an exception to subsection 215id1 waivers may be granted even if nonconforming structures will be enlarged or altered as a result of the waiver f a granted waiver and any conditions attached to it shall be entered on the face of or attached to the development order or permit and development plan g a proposed modification to an approved waiver shall be added to the approved waiver and considered in the aggregate the total waiver approved waiver plus proposed modification shall determine the approving authority per subsection a exh a  6 51412   downtown maitland development standards manual the downtown maitland development standards manual also known as the pattern book in the citys cdp shall be used to guide the future development and redevelopment of the downtown maitland special district toward creating an attractive urban pattern that balances the pedestrian and traffic needs of residents while it protects and enhances the original pattern of development consistent with the goals of the citys comprehensive plan downtown master plan and the downtown maitland revitalization plan the downtown maitland development standards manual functions as a supplement to these regulations and provides 1 additional detailed design standards for building form and architecture related to windows and doors building materials building colors and roof design as well as streetscape furnishing 2 visual examples fundamental design principles and comprehensive direction for the implementation of the regulations included within section 232 and 3 parking standards including singleuse parking ratios and shared parking standards without the necessity of providing additional parking studies the downtown maitland development standards manual shall be adopted or modified by resolution of the city council exh a  6 51412   circulation streets figure vi1 of the downtown maitland development standards manual shows the various street types within the downtown maitland zoning district the following subsections contain the design standards for streets in the downtown developers are encouraged to modify the design of the street along the entire block from intersection to intersection for design consistency if the developer is not modifying the entire block relocating the curb will not be required  however adequate area for parkway and sidewalk must be provided consistent with the following standards i street type imajor commercial streets  there are two 2 major commercial streets in the downtown orlando avenue and horatio avenue east of orlando avenue street type activity area of orlando avenue sybelia avenue sybelia parkway george avenue independence lane swoope avenue packwood avenue ventris avenue manor road lake avenue park avenue monroe avenue lewis drive and elvin avenue there are several acceptable variations of this street type but the city will encourage consistent design along entire blocks please refer to the table below street type ii activity area parallel parking travel lane type iii with onstreet parking and parkway 8 to 20 feet 6 feet 6 feet 9 feet 10 feet min iv street type ivalleysaccess roads  the purpose of alleys is to minimize the for alleys shall not exceed sixteen 16 feet for one 1 way alleys and twenty 20 feet for two 2 way alleys travel lane width shall not exceed twelve 12 feet for one 1 way traffic and eighteen 18 feet for two 2 way traffic nine 9 feet per lane minimum street type activity area sidewalk parkway parallel parking travel lane type iv one 1 way na na 2 feet na 12 feet type iv two 2 way na na 2 feet na 18 feet exh a  6 51412 network patterns site access and circulation shared access and circulation systems shall be designed to minimize curb cuts provide direct access between adjacent uses and improve traffic circulation a joint access driveways and crossaccess easements are required between sites to reduce the number of access points and driveway area and to increase the amount of landscaping b access driveway width shall be limited to twelve 12 feet for one 1 way driveways and twenty 20 feet for two 2 way driveways the crossing area connecting the sidewalk over the access driveway shall be distinct from the pavement and consistent with the required street furnishings as required in the downtown maitland design standards manual if a median is provided between two 2 driveways then the crosswalk must continue median c when it is feasible to provide vehicular access to a commercial site from a secondary street or access road without negatively impacting abutting singlefamily residential uses it shall be required unless city council grants an exception to such requirement in association with the approval of a design waiver as provided in section 2322 d projects shall be designed to create a balanced transportation system that invites pedestrians bicyclists and transit riders as well as motor vehicles and provides a system of connections to maximize choices for all modes of travel e nonresidential and mixeduse developments with a gross floor area of fifty thousand 50000 gross square feet or more which are adjacent to a street that is or may be used as a transit route shall coordinate with lynx and if recommended by lynx and required by the city shall provide access for an onsite public transit stop the public transit stop shall include a bus pullout and shelter please refer to the downtown maitland design standards manual street furnishings for bus shelter design f the number of curb cuts along the street frontage shall be limited in areas such as the orlando avenue corridor the vehicular entrances are encouraged to be from side streets and rear access roads exh a  6 51412 parking garages the design of a public garage shall adhere to the following standards a vehicle entrances to structured parking garages shall be located away from primary pedestrian activity areas b pedestrian access to parking garages shall be provided directly from adjacent streets c when fronting pedestrianoriented spaces at least seventyfive 75 percent of ground floor parking garage frontage exclusive of entrance driveways stairwells and pedestrian entryways shall consist of active uses other than parking such as residential where allowed pd process offices retail personal services civic uses and entertainment businesses the city may approve other design alternatives such as a liner building around the outer edge of the garage designed to achieve this intent d the space provided for active uses shall be at least thirty 30 feet deep along its entire length e parking garages shall comply with all building design standards for building facade scale building features and lighting compatibility and placement on the site as provided in sections 216 2324 2325 and 2326 of this the downtown maitland development standards manual f parking garages are exempt from the floor height requirements of subsection 216iie3c and the step back requirements of subsection 216iie3 exh a  6 51412   41116  pedestrian and bicycle circulation i pedestrian circulationaccess  pedestrian connections will be required as follows a along orlando avenue direct pedestrian access shall be provided from the principal entrance of the building to the sidewalk on the closest public rightofway b additionalsecondary pedestrian access to businesses may be provided from the parking facilities directly to the ground floor uses either building entrances sidewalks along the perimeter of buildings or by pedestrian alleyways or pathways which connect the rear parking lots to the sidewalks along the front street pedestrian alleyways and pathways shall be a minimum of ten 10 feet wide c pedestrian circulation within the development shall be differentiated from driving surfaces change in materials and elevation and shall provide locations for protection from the weather d crosswalks are required wherever pedestrian circulation intersects a vehicular area ii bicycle circulation and access  the following standards will promote the continued use of bicycles as a viable means of transportation a all new development is required to provide connections to the citys bike and pedestrian path system if feasible b bicycle racks shall be permanently fixed to the surface fasteners or use of concrete footings c the provision and design of bicycle racks shall be in accordance with the standards in the downtown maitland development standards manual exh a  6 51412   site design and lot layout blocklot layout a applicants may be required to create streets or access easements developments to interconnect the local traffic in the area rather than creating selfcontained developments b the internal design of a development shall accommodate pedestrian circulation throughout exh a  6 51412 building placement and orientation building orientation refers to the location of the primary and secondary facades and entrances to a building a buildings pads shall meet the required buildtolinesetbacks and building frontage requirements to reinforce street edges along all public rightsofway b buildings shall orient toward the public rightofway c if a site fronts on more than one 1 public rightofway such as a corner or double frontage lot the development shall be designed to respond to both rightsofway if not feasible the placement and orientation of the building shall be determined by the city on a casebycase basis d outparcels shall not be exempt from the requirements of this section exh a  6 51412 activity area the following standards apply to structures within the activity area a the use of arcades galleries or other integral architectural features that provide protection from the elements shall be required within the activity area along independence avenue b arcades and galleries must provide a twelve 12 foot minimum vertical clearance on the first floor c the minimum depth for arcades and galleries shall be eight 8 feet d floors above an arcade or gallery shall be allowed to encroach into the activity area for the entire depth of the arcade or gallery e buildings may be setback up to twenty 20 feet from the buildtoline for the provision of pedestrian forecourts courtyards plazas cafes or other public gathering places the additional setback shall not be applied to more than fifty 50 percent of the building width a low street wall shall be installed at the required buildtoline or along the sidewalk for the length of the recess to maintain continuity along the street front see street wall standards section subsection 23ivc1 exh a  6 51412 service areasutilities a utility lines of all kinds shall be installed and constructed in accordance with section 520 b nonresidential delivery and loading areas areas for outdoor storage trash collection and mechanical equipment shall be located away from property lines abutting residential areas c loading areas or docks outdoor storage waste disposal mechanical equipment satellite dishes truck parking and other service support equipment shall be located behind the building line and shall be fully screened from the view of adjacent properties d areas for outdoor storage trash collection and loading shall be incorporated into the primary building design and construction for these areas shall be of materials of comparable quality and appearance as that of the primary building e shopping cart storage shall be located inside the building or shall be screened by a four 4 foot wall consistent with the building architecture and materials exh a  6 51412 stormwater design per subsection 216iii all developments within an area permitted for a regional pond shall connect to the regional pond for sites that are eligible for providing onsite stormwater management the following standards shall be met a underground storage and exfiltration are encouraged b all retention areas shall be incorporated into the overall design of the project c ponds shall not be located adjacent to public rightsofway  they shall be located to the side or rear of a development d wet stormwater areas shall be designed as amenities features such as fountains or aerators shall be required to accent the ponds and provide adequate aeration to prevent stagnation and fish kills e landscaping is required to soften the visual appearance of the ponds edges native trees and shrubs shall be used to landscape the littoral zone no exotic invasive plants are permitted f subject to the requirements of st johns river water management district other governmental agencies and a consideration of safety related issues stormwater facilities shall be prohibited from having fencing unless it can be demonstrated to be necessary due to the configuration and topography of the lot the determination of necessity in this circumstance shall be made by the appropriate decision making authority as a part of the evaluation of a design waiver to these standards g whether stormwater is provided onsite or offsite developers are encouraged to use low impact design concepts such as rain water harvesting green roofs bioswales rain gardens parking lot water capture and pervious pavement the goal of encouraging the use of these mechanisms is to reduce stormwater runoff capture contaminants closer to the source and reduce the use of potable water for irrigation and grey water activities exh a  6 51412 landscaping and screening standards i general requirements  a a minimum of one 1 tree shall be planted or preserved for every five thousand 5000 square feet of site area trees planted as part of the parking lot andor buffer yard landscaping requirements may count toward this requirement in lieu of providing the trees onsite applicants may choose to pay into the citys tree fund b plant materials for landscaping buffering and screening shall be chosen from the floridafriendly plant database central florida region this database which is maintained by the university of florida institute of food and agricultural sciences ufifas may be accessed online at wwwfloridayardsorgfyplantsindexphp c additional plants may be approved by the citys arborist upon written request all proposed trees and plant materials shall be graded as nursery grade no 1 or better as outlined by the florida department of agriculture and consumer services division of plant industry grades and standards for nursery plants latest edition as revised from time to time d to minimize water consumption the use of vegetative ground cover with lowwater demand is encouraged rather than turf 1 no more than thirty 30 percent of the site landscaping shall be planted with sod if it is a high water use species st augustine 2 no more than fifty 50 percent shall be planted with a low water use sod species 3 sod shall not be used in areas less than four 4 feet in width e palm trees shall be limited to forty 40 percent of the total tree requirement f canopy trees that are planted closer than six 6 feet from a curb andor sidewalk shall be planted with a root barrier control method that is approved by the city public works director g all plant containers shall be irrigated with micro irrigation on a separate dedicated irrigation zone refer to chapter 8 article vi and chapter 20 article iv of the citys land development code for irrigation requirements ii parkway landscaping  parkways shall include the following landscaping materials which shall not be counted toward the required onsite landscaping a street trees  the following street trees are required to be planted within the parkway districtstreet type tree type spacing caliper height spread clearance minimum soil volume packwood type i d d blanchard magnolia 50 4 1214 67 14 vehicular  8 pedestrian 1000 cf  16 root diameter type ii live oak cultivar 50 5 1719 911 palms in conjunction with option 3 only see section 23 30 na 14 clear trunk na na 300 cf  8 root diameter sawmill and waterhouse type i live oak cultivar 50 4 1517 68 14 vehicular  8 pedestrian 1000 cf  16 root diameter type ii live oak cultivar 50 5 1517 68 type iii intermediate or 30 4 1315 67 300 cf  8 root diameter palms 30 na 14 clear trunk na na  centrally located within the parkway except along type i streets where the tree shall be planted at least eight 8 feet from the curb and four 4 feet from the sidewalk where the parkway is interspersed with onstreet parking the street tree must be located within a bump out which shall be at least ten 10 feet wide and as deep as the parking space b shrubs groundcover and accent plants  shrubs ground covers and accent plants shall be used in the parkway areas accent plants must be in scale with the sizes of surrounding plantings and must be significant in size to provide visual impact at planting sod is not allowed within the parkway areas plant type specifications size spacing groundcover 1 gallon 1224 oc depending on plant species low shrub 3 gallon 2430 oc depending on plant species medium shrub 3 gallon 2430 oc depending on plant species accent shrub 7 gallon as shown on approved landscape plans iii activity area landscaping  a street types i and ii  the activity areas along street types i and ii are intended to be used for pedestrian activity and if not occupied with arcades or galleries they shall be used as an extension of the sidewalk as outdoor seating area or for street furniture landscaping in this area if provided shall be in the form of containers andor planter boxes in scale and consistent with the building mass and architecture activity areas in front of uses that do not require pedestrian interaction along the facade eg churches offices multifamily shall meet the requirements for street type iii b street type iii  activity areas along a street type iii shall be landscaped with a combination of intermediate trees palms shrubs vines andor ground covers subject to the size and spacing requirements of sections 23iia and b iv parking lot landscaping and screening  parking lot design layout landscaping buffering and screening shall minimize direct views of parked vehicles from streets and sidewalks  and avoid spillover light glare noise and exhaust fumes onto adjacent properties a landscape strips between parking aisles  large parking lots shall be visually and functionally segmented into smaller lots with landscaped islands and strips parking lots with more than two 2 headtohead rows of parking shall include a continuous six 6 foot wide landscape strip between the parking spaces parallel to the drive aisle the strip shall be provided every other double row of parking the following trees shall be planted within the landscape strip tree type spacing caliper height spread clearance minimum soil volume intermediate 30 4 1012 4 14 vehicular 8 pedestrian 300 cf  8 root diameter palm trees clusters of 3 30 na 14 clear trunk na na na  varies depending on species b landscape islands  no more than ten 10 consecutive parking stalls are permitted without a landscape island at least eight 8 feet wide measured from back of curb and extending the entire length of the parking stall a minimum of one 1 canopy tree or either two 2 intermediate trees or three 3 palm trees shall be planted in each landscape island the trees must meet the caliper height spread clearance and soil volume noted in the previous sections a minimum of five 5 shrubs per one hundred and fortyfour 144 square feet of landscape area shall also be planted in the landscape island the remainder shall be filled with a combination of mulch and ground cover c parking lot perimeter screening  the landscaping within the parking lot perimeter along the side and rear property lines shall meet the requirements of section 815c the parking lot perimeter landscaping along the front property line may be located within the activity area and shall meet the following requirements 1 street wall  in order to minimize direct views of parked vehicles from streets and sidewalks a street wall shall be provided along the perimeter of surface parking lots fronting on public streets or alleys the street wall shall meet the following standards a decorative street walls shall be constructed of wrought iron brick masonry stone or other decorative materials matching the building materials and style the use of cast stone squares to match the sidewalk is encouraged b chain link and wood street walls shall be prohibited c the wall shall be a minimum of three 3 feet and a maximum of five 5 feet in height walls greater than three 3 feet in height above grade shall be no more than fifty 50 percent solid d the wall may be located anywhere within the width of the activity area but shall in no case allow for less than a two 2 foot wide strip of landscaping e street walls shall incorporate raised lintels to protect existing trees and bridge over their existing root system f the quality of the street wall materials shall match or exceed the quality of materials used for the building construction the finish used on the street wall shall match or compliment the finishes on the building 2 landscaping  ground cover hedges or shrubs shall be installed on both sides of the wall on the inside of the wall either intermediate or palm trees shall be planted see section 23d1 for tree specifications v buffers  the buffer yard requirements contained in section 813 buffer yard landscape regulations shall only apply to development abutting residentiallyzoned sites and only along the property line shared by the two 2 uses no buffers shall be required between any other uses unless specifically required as part of a conditional use approval vi stormwater pond landscaping  if an onsite retention pond is approved by the city it shall be designed to include a minimum ten 10 foot wide landscape buffer along the ponds perimeter the buffer shall include one 1 canopy tree or a cluster of three 3 understory trees for every fifty 50 linear feet of landscape buffer this landscape buffer must not interfere with the required maintenance shelf exh a  6 51412 parking lot lighting in addition to perimeter streets lights requirements that were provided in the downtown maitland development standards manual the followings parking lot lighting standards are applicable a light fixtures shall be designed so that light is directed onto the parking area and away from neighboring residential lots b light fixtures shall be equipped with dark sky light shields c lighting fixtures in parking lots adjacent to residential zones shall not exceed twenty 20 feet in height as measured from the adjacent grade to the top of the light fixture d parking lot lighting fixture design shall be complimentary to the street light design as required in the downtown maitland design standards manual e tree and site lighting locations shall not be in conflict exh a  6 51412   building form and architecture building frontage a in order to create a continuous urban form along all streets the following minimum building frontage requirements shall be met the standards are stated as percentage of the building width at the buildtoline to the lot width  packwood   seventyfive 75 percent  waterhouse   fifty 50 percent  sawmill   fifty 50 percent sites with multiple street frontages shall meet the frontage requirement along all streets if not feasible waivers will be considered by the city on a casebycase basis based on site location and street priorities b front facades along street types i and ii shall limit the number of gaps along the block face should a vehicular access be necessary due to lack of access to rear parking from a secondary street an alley or an adjacent property shared use agreement necessary a gateway arch or similar feature shall be provided to preserve the block continuity the width of the driveway shall not exceed twelve 12 feet for one 1 way traffic and twenty 20 feet for two 2 way traffic exh a  6 51412   development incentives the city provides the following opportunities for development incentives to encourage development and redevelopment activity within the downtown maitland zoning district and the downtown maitland special district exh a  6 51412   81417  incentives program a expedited review and application process  ii provides an expedited review and application process for downtown maitland a cra staff person is available to assist applicants development review permitting process andor development agreement process if necessary applications for incentives that involve payments into trust funds or purchases of credits require either the execution of a development agreement with final site plan review or approval as provided in subsection 7583ivc refer to subsection 7583ivc for additional process standards b offsite infrastructure  applicants may apply for offsite accommodation of their required open space pervious surface andor parking see section vib of the development standards manual offsite infrastructure may be accommodated at a city facility or an offsite private property if available eligibility for participation in the provision of infrastructure offsite shall be requested during the preapplication meeting prior to any formal development review procedures eligibility requires the availability of the appropriate capacity at the designated donor site once eligibility is determined and the required onsite capacities established the developer may reserve the capacity not fulfilled onsite the developer must submit proof of offsite capacity in the form of an agreement between the developer and the owner of the donor site at the time of application for development approval the agreement is subject to city approval and shall run with the land exh a  6 51412 reserved editors note  2 adopted  repealed  23 which pertained to bonus programs and derived from exh a  6 51412   41116    downtown maitland sign standards a monument signs  no reader boards are allowed all signs must include visible street number address b for properties with commercial retail uses under forty thousand 40000 square feet gross building area   signs can be internally or externally lit  sign area shall be a maximum of thirtysix 36 square feet per face  maximum height of sign shall be eight 8 feet  a minimum of two 2 feet tall masonry or stone base is required c for properties wcommercial retail uses over forty thousand 40000 square feet gross building area   signs can be internally or externally lit  sign area shall be a maximum of seventytwo 72 square feet per face  maximum height of sign shall be twelve 12 feet  signs shall be masonry or stone only  a minimum of two 2 feet tall masonry or stone base is required d for office uses under twenty thousand 20000 square feet gross building area   sign area shall be a maximum of thirtysix 36 square feet per face  maximum height of sign shall be eight 8 feet  a minimum of two 2 feet tall masonry or stone base is required  signs shall be externally illuminated only e for office uses over twenty thousand 20000 square feet gross building area   sign area shall be a maximum of seventytwo 72 square feet per face  maximum height of sign shall be twelve 12 feet  signs shall be masonry or stone only  signs shall be externally illuminated only f for residential uses   sign area shall be a maximum of thirtysix 36 square feet per face when total dwelling units are one hundred 100 or less  sign area shall be a maximum of seventytwo 72 square feet per face when total dwelling units are over one hundred 100  maximum height of sign shall be eight 8 feet when total dwelling units are one hundred 100 or less  maximum height of sign shall be twelve 12 feet when total dwelling units are over one hundred 100  one 1 face per street front  signs shall be perpendicular to the streets no v signs allowed  signs shall be externally illuminated only  signs shall be masonry or stone only g signs erected on buildings including canopy awning   maximum allowable sign copy area for signs erected on buildings including canopy awning   one and onehalf 112 square feet per every linear foot of street frontage this maximum allowable copy area may be increased by ten 10 percent for any buildings higher than thirtyfive 35 feet  no window signs are allowed other than lettering of numbers for addresses or legally required notices 1 wall arcade blade attached to building   maximum size   eighty 80 square feet minimum twelve 12 feet above sidewalk 2 canopy awning   maximum sign size   thirty 30 percent of awning face area  no pole or pylon signs are allowed exh a  6 51412 code comparative table  1971 code this table gives the location within this those sections of the 1971
